{{primary sources|date=December 2010}} '''Aimé Michel''' (12 May 1919 in [[Saint-Vincent-les-Forts]] – 28 December 1992), was a [[Unidentified flying object|UFO]] specialist.
== Biography == Educated with diplomas in [[psychology]] and [[philosophy]], '''Aimé Michel''' joined the French Radio Broadcasting<ref>[[Radiodiffusion Française]] which was later known as RTF and then ORTF</ref> in 1944. (He had successfully passed an entrance exam for studio sound engineers in 1943.) In 1946, he worked in the research department, making contact with [[Pierre Schaeffer]] (a member of the association "Work and Culture" (''Travail et Culture'') in association with [[Louis Pauwels]]).
In 1958, with the publication of his book about the 1954 wave of UFOs (''Mystérieux Objets Célestes'') in France, Michel devised a theory called [[orthoténie]] with the help of [[Jacques Bergier]] on the corner of a restaurant tablecloth.<ref>''About Flying Saucers - Mysterious Celestial Objects (OMC)'', Aimé Michel, coll. ''Planet Presence'', Planet Ed, 1966, p.134</ref> Michel posited so-called "alignments": Straight lines which corresponded to large circles traced and centered on the earth. Michel claimed that UFO sightings could be concentrated along these grid lines. He proposed, for example, that there was a line known as “Bavic” (for “[[Bayonne]] - [[Vichy]]”) where, out of nine UFO observations cited in the press on 24 September 1954, six aligned ([[Bayonne]], [[Lencouacq]], [[Tulle]], [[Ussel, Corrèze|Ussel]], [[Gelles]], [[Vichy]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ignaciodarnaude.com/ufologia/Saunders,BAVIC%20Orthotenic%20Line,FSR71V17N4.pdf |title=Is Bavic Remarkable? |last1=Saunders |first1=David R. |website=Ufologia Heterodoxa |publisher=Ignacio Darnaude Rojas-Marcos |format=PDF |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref>
A member of the editorial board of ''Lights in the Night'' (''Lumières dans la nuit'') since 1969, he wrote numerous articles on UFOs, mysticism, the animal kingdom as well as other topics in various journals.<ref>(''Arts'', ''[[Science et Vie]]'', ''[[Tout Savoir]]'', ''[[Monde et Vie]]'', ''[[Encyclopédie Larousse]]'' « Découvrir les Animaux » in 1971, ''[[Planète (revue)|Planète]]'' - apologist for [[Réalisme fantastique]] including other participants [[Remy Chauvin]], [[Bernard Heuvelmans]], [[Charles Noël Martin]], [http://perso.wanadoo.fr/autre.realite/Annexe1.htm Jean E. Charon] and [[George Langelaan]] -, ''[[Phénomènes Spatiaux]]'', ''Recherches ufologiques'', ''Question de'', ''France Catholique'', ''Ecclésia'', ''[[Flying Saucer Review]]'', ''[[Archeologia]]'' (with an article on his village where he was born), etc.)</ref> In the journal ''The Life of the Animals'' (''[[La vie des bêtes]]''), during the 1960s, he authored the column ''The Mysteries of the Animal Kingdom'' (''Les mystères du monde animal''). From September 26 to October 10, 1964, Aimé Michel also led cultural workshops on the theme of "Life in the Sidereal Universe" (''La vie dans l'Univers sidéral''), taking place under the auspices of the magazine ''Planet'' (''Planète'') at Cefalu in Sicily.
He wrote the television screenplay [[Mycènes Celui qui vient du futur]]: Mycènes, He who comes from the future.
His readers generally appreciate his interest in "anything that is beyond human" and in challenges of the mind. Described as a free spirit by his entourage, Michel had a stated goal to avoid being limited by external constraints.
He was a friend of the controversial Jacques Bergier and Louis Pauwels, and described himself as a "pathological" rebel.
== Works == *''Heroic Mountains, A History of Mountaineering'' (''Montagnes héroïques, histoire de l'alpinisme''), ed. Mame, 1953, collection Découvertes: This is a layman's book on the history of mountaineering in the world. Michel Aimé writes about the exploits of climbers from the dawn of history to the most recent of expeditions. *''Glimmering lights on flying saucers'' (''Lueurs sur les soucoupes volantes'') (edition Mame, 1954, coll. ''Découvertes''; preface by his friend [[Jean Cocteau]]) is the second book on French UFOs, following ''Flying Saucers Come From Another World'' (''Les soucoupes volantes viennent d'un autre monde''), written by Jimmy Guieu (edition Fleuve Noir, 1954) but before ''Propulsion of Flying Saucers'' (''Propulsion des soucoupes volantes'') written by Jean Plantier (edition. Mame, 1955). Published in English as ''The Truth About Flying Saucers'' (Robert Hale, 1957; Corgi paperback, 1958). *''About Flying Saucers" ("Mystérieux objects célestes"), ed. Arthaud, 1958, coll. "Clefs de l'Adventure/Clefs du Savoir," new ed. Planète (Présence Planète), 1966; new ed. Robert Laffont (Malesherbes) and Seghers, 1977: A study devoted to an outbreak of UFOs in France in late 1954. Michael claimed to be the first to detect "[[orthoteny|rows]]" in the sightings. *''The Voice'' poets, spring 1960, a collective tribute to [[Jean Cocteau]] text [[François Reichenbach]] *''The Mystery of Dreams'' (with Wilhelm Moufang, William O. Stevens), World Encyclopedia, 1965. *''The Animal performance'', ed. Hachette, 1966, coll. "The Adventure of Life." *''History and Guide to Secret France'' (with [[John Paul Clébert]]), Encyclopedia Planet, No. 31, 1968, repr. Denoël, 1979, "Legends and Traditions of France" My spiritual journey through France, seen and unseen. Birth of the sacred: the France of megaliths: the Gallic Charm: France says no: the long march (mountaineering and alchemy): routes: guide to the fantastic and wonderful, a geography of the sacred (France swallowed: Wild France: France sanctuaries: Traditional France: Haunted France: Miraculous France (signs in the sky): France as sacred space. *''From animal to man: an interview with Konrad Lorenz'' by [[Jacques Brissot]], documentary film, writer Aimé Michel, 1968, ORTF al. "Un certain regard", 50 '. *''For or against the Flying Saucers'' (with George Lear), ed. Berger-Levrault, 1969 * Mysterious''flying saucers'' (with [[Jacques Vallée]] and Fernand Lagarde "Lights in the Night"), ed. Albatros, 1973, repr. 1976 *''The mysticism, the inner man and the ineffable'', ed. Culture, Arts and Leisure (CAL - CELT), 1973, coll. "Library of the Irrational and the Great Mysteries: Psychology of the ineffable. Abnormal surnormal. The alchemy of pain. Marie-Madeleine de Pazzi or the abyss of love. Carve the meat. The body of the soul to the sources. The ninth key. Conclusion: beyond human rights *''Metanoia, physical phenomena of mysticism,'' ed. Albin Michel, 1973, repr. 1986, coll. "Modern Spirituality" series "Comparative Religion", No. 57 (revised and enlarged rééd. ''mysticism, the inner man and the ineffable''). *''In Search of humanoids'' (with Jacques Vallee, Charles Bowen (director of "Flying Saucer Review and author of the book), Antonio Ribera, William T. Powers, Gordon Creighton, Coral Lorenzen, Dr. W. Buhler, etc.), ed. Lu I, et al. "The Mysterious Adventure", 1974. *''The Extra-Sensory / Calculators prodigies,'' volume of the collection ''The Unknown Powers of Man'' (14 volumes), ed. Chu-Laffont, 1976-1977: two texts Aimé Michel: ''These extra-sensory surround us'' in the introduction, ''Towards a new key of dreams'' about dreams in the second section "Creating and creativity." *''The end of the world?'' Resumption of items under the aegis of Louis Pauwels an issue of the journal "Question" on the subject, ed. Retz (or Albin Michel?), 1977. *''''Mysterious celestial objects'', repr. Robert Laffont, 1977, coll. "The other worlds and their riddles." Enriched (same year: repr. Malesherbes, and repr. Seghers). *''The Hidden Face of France'' (with Jean-Paul Clébert Pierre Crepon, Jean-Michel Varenne and Jacques Brosse), coll. Memory ''Cheers,'' Volume I, ed. Seghers, 1978 (edited by Louis Pauwels, preface). Chapter AM: "The Soul of France through the folk tradition." *''Soft'' The Apocalypse, ed. Aldana, 2008. Preface by Jacques Vallee. This book consists of original texts by the author learned of the correspondence addressed to Bertrand Méheust from 1978 to 1990. *''Clarity in the heart of the labyrinth'', ed. Aldana, 2008. Chronicles on science and religion from the magazine ''[[Catholic France]]''. Selected Writings, introduced and annotated by Jean-Pierre Rospars.

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Angela "Ala" Paredes |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|04|17}} |birth_place = |residence = Sydney, Australia |nationality = |citizenship = [[Australian citizen|Australian]] |other_names = |known_for = environmental activist, vocalist, tv personality, model |education = Bachelor of Arts in Communication(2004) |alma_mater = [[Ateneo de Manila University]] |employer = ABS CBN Global |occupation = Correspondent |years_active = 2001–present |home_town = Quezon City, Philippines |title = |height = |weight = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = [[Jim Paredes]] (Father) Lydia Paredes (Mother) |relations = Erica Paredes (Sister) Mio Paredes(Brother) |signature = |website = http://ala-ism.pansitan.net |footnotes = }}'''Angela "Ala" Paredes''' is an Australia-based [[Filipino people|Filipino]] environmental activist, commercial model and writer, who at various times in her career was also a TV host, VJ, advice columnist, and vocalist for [[Pinoy rock|Filipino alternative]] band Hiraya. Since moving to Australia, she has become one of the correspondents covering Australia for the Philippines' [[ABS-CBN News & Current Affairs]].
== Education and early career == Paredes graduated from high school in 2000 at the [[School of the Holy Spirit]] (SHSQC), a private, all-girls [[Roman Catholic school]] in [[Quezon City]]. She then moved on to the [[Ateneo de Manila University]], where she received her Bachelor of Arts in Communication in 2004.
She first ventured into modeling in her junior year in college, doing a commercial for a facial wash, and soon endorsing a clothing line. Initially, Ala was perceived to have the advantage of a familiar family name: she is the second daughter of singer [[Jim Paredes]] of the [[APO Hiking Society]]. But she soon became popular in her own right, taking up social causes just as her father, well known for his advocacies, did before her.<ref name="faces">{{Cite news | author-link = | title = The many faces of Ala Paredes | newspaper = Manila Bulletin | date = September 22, 2005 | url =http://www.articlearchives.com/humanities-social-science/visual-performing-arts-music/493643-1.html }}</ref><ref name="greenpeace">{{cite web|last=Baclagon |first=Chuck |authorlink=Chuck Baclagon |title=Sailing the high seas, and dancing for clean energy: Ala Paredes writes blogumentary about life on the Rainbow Warrior |work=Greenpeace Southeast Asia: News |publisher=Greenpeace Southeast Asia |date=November 30, 2005 |url=http://www.greenpeace.org/seasia/en/news/alaism_rw_blog |accessdate=September 27, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522124901/http://www.greenpeace.org/seasia/en/news/alaism_rw_blog |archivedate=May 22, 2008 }}</ref> Model in Globe Telecom's TV Ad "ARE YOU ONE OF US?" early 2000
== "Unconventional Beauty"== In her first forays as a television personality, doing television ads, she quickly became a recognizable figure,{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} distinguished by her morena (malay brown) complexion and curly hair, a sharp contrast to the traditional look of models at the time. The [[Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism]] took note of her unusual success and said: :''Model Ala Paredes has curly hair in a country where long, straight hair is considered the epitome of female beauty.... In an industry that prizes fair skin and straight hair, her morena skin color and loose, voluptuous curls are considered unconventional.''<ref name="pcij">{{cite journal | last = Chan | first = Cheryl | authorlink = Cheryl Chan | title = Focus on Filipino Youth: The Business of Beauty | journal = IReport | issue = 3 | publisher = Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism | location = Quezon City | date = September 2005 | url = http://www.pcij.org/i-report/3/beauty2.html | id = | accessdate =February 5, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080122062256/http://www.pcij.org/i-report/3/beauty2.html| archivedate= January 22, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
At around the same time, Paredes began blogging regularly, with her blog soon becoming popular{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} and earning her a reputation as a celebrity blogger<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pep.ph/news/12586/celebrity-bloggers-judge-candy-magazine39s-2007-teen-blog-awards|title=Celebrity bloggers judge Candy Magazine's 2007 Teen Blog Awards|last=Villafuerte|first=Ingrid|date=March 22, 2007|website=Philippine Entertainment Portal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} – a role she would later use to promote environmental issues.<ref name="greenpeace"/>
==Media work in the Philippines== Paredes' modeling career soon burgeoned into a television career.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} She continued modelling occasionally but became a regular VJ for [[ABS-CBN]]'s music channel [[Myx]], and then later the host of IslaMusik, a television show on [[TV5 (Philippines)|ABC 5]] featuring a musicians from all over the Philippines. She also often served as a presenter at numerous events.<ref name="faces"/> As a writer, she also became an advice columnist for Pink magazine.<ref name="faces"/>
== Hiraya vocalist == In 2005, Paredes became the frontwoman of a [[Pinoy rock]] band [[Hiraya (Band)|Hiraya]] when the original vocalist left. Guitarist Mark Verzo, bassist Marco Cuneta on bass, and drummer Paulo Tomas recruited her to become the replacement vocalist.<ref name="hiraya">{{cite web | title = The Flight of Hiraya | work = Bembang.com | publisher = Bembang! Online Magazine | date = August 30, 2005 | url=http://www.bembang.com/view.php?id=76 | accessdate =February 5, 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080228072740/http://bembang.com/view.php?id=76| archivedate= February 28, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The band had already released an EP, with their previous vocalist, when Ala took over.<ref name="faces"/> She stayed with the band until a short time before she moved to Australia with her family in 2006.
== Move to Australia == In 2006, the Paredes family decided to [[Immigration to Australia|migrate to Australia]] – a decision which Jim Paredes explained was related to a desire for greater personal development. The move generated some controversy when a copyeditor for a prominent Philippine newspaper wrote a headline that said Mr. Paredes, known for his activism, was "giving up on the Philippines." Both Jim and Ala Paredes protested that this was a miscategorization of their family's motives for moving. The paper eventually apologized to the Paredes family for the original, inaccurate headline of the article.<ref name="lirio">{{Cite news |last=Lirio |first=Gerry |authorlink=Gerry Lirio |title=Apo’s Jim Paredes on his move to Australia |newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=August 20, 2006 |url=http://services.inquirer.net/print/print.php?article_id=16183 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903003841/http://services.inquirer.net/print/print.php?article_id=16183 |archivedate=September 3, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref> Mr Paredes later said that he "''felt bad not so much that people misread me as a person (that's hurtful, yes) but more so that they may slip deeper into despair by such a false story. That's the last thing we need,''"<ref name="lirio"/><ref>{{cite web |last=Paredes |first=Jim |authorlink=Jim Paredes |title=' Pick up the feathers, you jerk.' |work=Writing on Air |date=August 20, 2008 |url=http://haringliwanag.pansitan.net/2006/08/pick-up-feathers-you-jerk.html |accessdate=December 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100101183104/http://haringliwanag.pansitan.net/2006/08/pick-up-feathers-you-jerk.html |archivedate=January 1, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> and Ala expressed similar sentiments.<ref name="lirio"/><ref>{{cite web |last=Paredes |first=Ala |authorlink=Ala Paredes |title=this is immature, but i don't care |work=Ala-ism |date=August 20, 2008 |url=http://ala-ism.pansitan.net/2006/08/this-is-immature-but-i-dont-care.html |accessdate=December 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917085002/http://ala-ism.pansitan.net/2006/08/this-is-immature-but-i-dont-care.html |archivedate=September 17, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref>
=== Media work and studies === Even after migrating to a new country, however, Ala Paredes continued to be deeply involved in things Filipino{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} – this time, specifically [[Filipino Australian|the Filipino community in Australia]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} In the same year that the Paredeses moved to Australia, she was recruited by ABS-CBN Global, the international multi-platform media company of Filipino media giant ABS-CBN, to be a correspondent for Balitang Australia, a weekly news and feature program catering specifically to Filipino Australians.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Filipino Channel: Programs |work=ABS CBN Global: In The Service of the Filipino Worldwide (Official Website) |publisher=ABS CBN Global |year=2006 |url=http://www.abs-cbnglobal.com/Products/TFC/Programs/tabid/233/ArticleID/209/TargetModuleID/1094/Default.aspx |format=aspx |accessdate=December 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025193030/http://www.abs-cbnglobal.com/Products/TFC/Programs/tabid/233/ArticleID/209/TargetModuleID/1094/Default.aspx |archivedate=October 25, 2008 |df=mdy }}</ref>
Paredes later decided to take up an [[illustration]] course from the [[Sydney Design Institute]], graduating in December 2009.<ref name="ampatuan">{{Cite news |last=Ramos |first=Marlon |authorlink=Marlon Ramos |title=Singer’s daughter sketches for Ampatuan trial |newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer |date=January 5, 2010 |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100105-245707/Singers-daughter-sketches-for-Ampatuan-trial |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108131518/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100105-245707/Singers-daughter-sketches-for-Ampatuan-trial |archivedate=January 8, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref>
=== Ampatuan trial sketch artist === Upon graduation, Paredes served as the official courtroom sketch artist at the trial of [[Andal Ampatuan Jr.]], the prime suspect in the [[Maguindanao massacre]].<ref name="SC"/> Paredes had gone on vacation in the Philippines to spend the holidays with relatives, when a friend of hers who worked at the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]] called about an open position for a courtroom sketch artist at the Ampatuan trial.<ref name="ampatuan"/> [[Courtroom sketch]]es were needed because media coverage at the trial was restricted.<ref name="SC">{{cite web | last =Marueñas | first =Mark Dalan | title = For the love of SC, Ala Paredes sketches massacre trial | work = GMANews.TV | publisher = GMA News and Public Affairs | date = January 13, 2010 | url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/181500/for-the-love-of-sc-ala-paredes-sketches-massacre-trial | accessdate =January 20, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100116162042/http://www.gmanews.tv/story/181500/for-the-love-of-sc-ala-paredes-sketches-massacre-trial| archivedate= January 16, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Describing the moment, she said that she ''“immediately called my friend back 10 seconds after receiving her message and accepted the offer. We did not talk about the (pay).”'' Noting the importance of the case, she said that ''“At a time when the nation is still grieving, I feel like this is my way of getting involved,”'' and ''“I thought this is my own way of giving public service, especially when media can’t be there.”''<ref name="ampatuan"/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox person |name =Alessia Marcuzzi<!-- SEE NOTE IN LEAD --> |image = |imagesize = |caption = |birth_name =Alessia Marcuzzi |birth_date ={{birth date and age|1972|11|11|df=y}} |birth_place =[[Rome]], [[Italy]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality =Italian |other_names = |known_for = |occupation =Actress, television presenter |years_active =1991 - present |spouse = {{marriage|Paolo Calabresi|2014}} |partner =[[Francesco Facchinetti]] (2010–2012) |salary = |religion = |parents = |website = |children ={{plainlist| *Tommaso Inzaghi (born 2001) *Mia Facchinetti (born 2011) }} }} '''Alessia Marcuzzi''' (born 11 November 1972) is an [[Italian people|Italian]] television host and actress.
== Biography == Born in [[Rome]], to father Eugenio, from [[Trieste]], and mother Antonietta from [[Roseto Valfortore]], in the province of [[Foggia]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Puka|first1=Genti|title=Alessia Marcuzzi|url=http://www.cinquantamila.it/storyTellerThread.php?threadId=MARCUZZI%20Alessia|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> she has debuted in [[Telemontecarlo]] hosting ''Attenti al dettaglio'' and then ''Qui si gioca'', with [[José Altafini]], in the 1991/1992 season. In March 1992 also presented the kids show ''Amici mostri''. In the 1992/1993 season hosted the entertainment show ''Novantatrè'', with [[Umberto Smaila]].<ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1992/novembre/27/Umberto_Smaila_gioca_sotto_Tenda_co_0_92112711953.shtml|title=Umberto Smaila gioca sotto la tenda|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=27 November 1992|page=38|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref> Has appeared in [[RAI]] televisions in 1994, with [[Gigi Sabani]], in ''Il grande gioco dell'oca''.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Davide Frattini|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1994/aprile/08/gioco_dell_oca_sulla_casella_co_0_9404084212.shtml|title=Il gioco dell'oca sulla casella risparmio|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=8 April 1994|page=36|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref> In 1994 also debuted as actress in the movies ''[[Chicken Park]]'', directed by [[Jerry Calà]], and ''Tra noi due è tutto finito''.
She started working in [[Mediaset]] from November 1995 hosting the [[Italia 1]] Saturday afternoon program ''Colpo di fulmine'', until June 1997. It became a daily show in 1996, because of his great success.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Stefania Ulivi|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1996/gennaio/23/Ambra_promossa_Sanremo_bocciata_Italia_co_0_9601231947.shtml|title=Ambra promossa a Sanremo, "bocciata" su Italia 1|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=23 January 1996|page=27|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref> Thanks to this program has become one of the most important [[Italia 1]] host; in this period she started hosting the well-known music festival ''[[Festivalbar]]'', from 1996 to 2002, with whom she won a ''[[Telegatto]]'' in 2001, has presented the late night show ''8 millimetri'' with Paolo Brosio and, from 1997 to 1998, the afternoon show ''Fuego!''.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Stefania Ulivi|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1997/dicembre/30/Alessia_rivelazione_dell_anno_co_0_97123013211.shtml|title=Alessia, la rivelazione dell'anno|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=30 December 1997|page=17|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref> She also presented the primetime show ''Mai dire Gol'', from 1998 to 2000, with [[Ellen Hidding]] and the [[Gialappa's Band]]. In these years acted in the movies ''[[Gunslinger's Revenge]]'', directed by [[Giovanni Veronesi]], ''Tutti gli uomini del deficiente'', and the TV movie ''Un cane e un poliziotto'' and the series ''Tequila & Bonetti'', acting with [[Jack Scalia]]. In 2000 hosted the pilot of ''Macchemù'', with [[Paola Barale]], dedicated to television themes and won the ''Oscar TV'' as "Personaggio televisivo femminile dell'anno".<ref>{{Cite news|author=Maria Volpe|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2000/aprile/06/Oscar_trionfano_Ricci_Cecchi_Paone_co_0_0004062312.shtml|title=Oscar Tv, trionfano Ricci e Cecchi paone. Le reazioni: "Premiate satira e cultura. Finalmente è finita l'era della frivolezza"|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=6 April 2000|page=37|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref>
From 2000 has replaced [[Simona Ventura]] in the Italian version of ''[[Caiga Quien Caiga]]'', named ''[[Le Iene]]'', presenting it until 2005, aired by [[Italia 1]] initially as late night show and then as primetime show.<ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2001/settembre/23/iene_doppio_appuntamento_con_Bisio_co_0_01092311787.shtml|title="Le iene", doppio appuntamento con Bisio e Alessia Marcuzzi|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=23 September 2001|page=39|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref>
In 2002 and 2003 she presented the [[Telegatto]]'s awards and, in 2003 too, the ''Galà della pubblicità'', with [[Heidi Klum]]; both the events were aired by [[Canale 5]].<ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2001/settembre/23/iene_doppio_appuntamento_con_Bisio_co_0_01092311787.shtml|title="Le iene", doppio appuntamento con Bisio e Alessia Marcuzzi|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=23 September 2001|page=39|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref> In [[Autumn]] 2003 has hosted the charity show ''La fabbrica del sorriso'', with [[Gerry Scotti]], [[Claudio Bisio]] and [[Michelle Hunziker]]. In the same years has won ''Premio Flaiano'' and another ''Oscar Tv'' for ''Le iene''.
After hosting an edition of ''Scherzi a parte'' in 2005, with [[Diego Abatantuono]] and [[Massimo Boldi]],<ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2005/gennaio/29/sara_finto_reality_Scherzi_parte_co_9_050129101.shtml|title=Ci sarà un finto reality a "Scherzi a parte"|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=29 January 2005|page=31|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref> in 2006 has replaced [[Barbara d'Urso]] presenting the Italian version of ''[[Big Brother (TV series)|Big Brother]]'', ''[[Grande Fratello]]'', that she's still hosting.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Emilia Costantini|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2006/gennaio/19/Grande_fratello_con_Marcuzzi_Casa_co_9_060119110.shtml|title=Grande fratello con la Marcuzzi. Casa divisa per ricchi e poveri e un milione di euro al vincitore|work=Corriere della Sera|location=Italy|date=19 January 2006|page=40|accessdate=24 January 2011|cid=|language=it}}</ref>
From 2004 to 2006, she was the protagonist of the television series ''Carabinieri'', while in 2007 she acted in ''Il giudice Mastrangelo 2''. Acted also in the TV movie ''Un amore di strega'', with [[Pietro Sermonti]], her partner in 2009, and in the sitcom ''Così fan tutte'', with [[Debora Villa]]. Her credits also include performances in various films and television, with starring roles in [[Leonardo Pieraccioni]]'s 1998 feature film ''[[Il mio West]]'', as well as the TV shows ''[[Tequila and Bonetti]]'' (2000) and ''[[Carabinieri (TV series)|Carabinieri]]''.
She had a child with [[Simone Inzaghi]], an Italian former footballer. After their separation, she had an affair with the Italian actor [[Pietro Sermonti]] and was engaged with the television host and singer [[Francesco Facchinetti]]<ref name=mia/> with whom has a daughter, Mia, born 4 September 2011. The relationship ended in October 2012.<ref name=mia>{{Cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.it/people/italia/2012/10/09/alessia-marcuzzi-francesco-facchinetti-fine-storia-amore-facebook-twitter |title=vanityfair.it |access-date=21 October 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021003301/http://www.vanityfair.it/people/italia/2012/10/09/alessia-marcuzzi-francesco-facchinetti-fine-storia-amore-facebook-twitter |archive-date=21 October 2012 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

'''Antoninus''' ([[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: Άντονίνoς; [[Latin]]: Antoninvs) was a member of the [[Late Roman army#Scholae|Household Cavalry]] under Emperor [[Constantius II]], and later a [[Sassanid Empire|Sassanid]] advisor to the [[Shah]] [[Shapur II]]. He played a key role in providing [[Military intelligence|intelligence]] to the Shah, culminating in the [[Looting|sack]] of [[Siege of Amida|Amida]] in 359 AD.
==Life== [[Ammianus Marcellinus]] is the only source on Antoninus:
:"There was a certain Antoninus, at first a rich merchant, then an accountant in the service of the governor of [[Mesopotamia (Roman province)|Mesopotamia]], and finally one of his body-guard, a man of experience and sagacity."<ref>{{cite book|last=Ammianus Marcellinus|title=Res Gestae|year=1982|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=18.5.1}}</ref> [[File:Diarbakir P1050574 20080427124233.JPG|thumb|Walls of [[Amida (Mesopotamia)|Amida]], modern [[Diyarbakır]], looking north from the eastern wall.]] Ammianus then goes on to describe how Antoninus had been mistreated by the imperial authorities of [[Constantius II]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Ammianus Marcellinus|title=Res Gestae|year=1982|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=18.5.1}}</ref> Having grown tired of losing property and wealth to corruption, Antoninus decided to become [[turncoat]]. After contacting the [[Sassanid Empire|Sassanid]] authorities, he crossed the [[Tigris]] river and joined Sassanids.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ammianus Marcellinus|title=Res Gestae|year=1982|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=18.5.3}}</ref> Antoninus later met [[Ursicinus (Roman general)|Ursicinus]] in the turn of events leading to the [[siege of Amida]]. Ammianus (who was present) noted how Antoninus had come to adopt the dress and customs of the [[Sassanid Empire|Sassanid]] [[Court (royal)|court]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Ammianus Marcellinus|title=Res Gestae|year=1982|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=18.8.5–6}}</ref>
There is nothing else known about Antoninus' life, aside from the high position in the [[Court (royal)|court]] of [[Shapur II]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Ammianus Marcellinus|title=Res Gestae|year=1982|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=19.9.8}}</ref> This may in part have been because he spoke both [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] and [[Latin]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Ammianus Marcellinus|title=Res Gestae|year=1982|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=18.5.1}}</ref>

'''Arne Ronold''' is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[Master of Wine]],<ref>mastersofwine.org, [http://www.mastersofwine.org/en/about/meet-the-masters/profile/index.cfm/id/FD8EE6BC-976B-47E1-A12E491B70B4CFB0 Masters of Wine, Arne Ronold profile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925083851/http://www.mastersofwine.org/en/about/meet-the-masters/profile/index.cfm/id/FD8EE6BC-976B-47E1-A12E491B70B4CFB0 |date=September 25, 2010 }}</ref> a [[journalist]] and editor of the Norwegian wine publication ''Vinforum'', and considered an expert on [[Italian wine|Italian]] and [[Burgundy wine]].
==Career== Ronold was from 1993 until 2008 the only MW of Norway,<ref name=aftbedre>Dalheim, Ulf, ''Adressa.no'' (October 28, 2008). [http://www.adressa.no/kultur/vin/article1179537.ece Best på vinkunnskap] {{no_icon}}</ref><ref name=D2Nov1408>{{cite web|last= Anker |first= Nils, ''Dagens Næringsliv: D2'' |title= – Vi skal gjøre oss fotjent til folks støtte |url= http://www.dn.no/d2/mat/article1538626.ece |date= November 14, 2008 |language= Norwegian }}</ref> and was the first in [[Scandinavia]] to attain the accreditation.<ref>Winewise.be [http://www.winewise.be/index.php/en/Tutors/Arne+Ronold+MW Arne Ronold MW] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823225739/http://www.winewise.be/index.php/en/Tutors/Arne%2BRonold%2BMW |date=August 23, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=aus>Winesfromaustria.com (November 2006). [http://www.winesfromaustria.com/archive/2006/ema_061116.html Austria’s Bacchus Prize 2006 to Arne Ronold MW] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513124701/http://www.winesfromaustria.com/archive/2006/ema_061116.html |date=May 13, 2008 }}</ref>
Prior to his career in wine he has a background in the research of theoretical physics, nuclear physics and mathematical flow models, with a degree in [[engineering]] from the [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]].
A co-author of several books, including ''Verdt å vite om vin'' and ''Italiensk Vin'', he annually publishes the pocket-sized consumer guides ''Norges beste vinkjøp''.<ref>Wessel, Monica, ''Aftenposten.no'' [http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/article1181665.ece Lommebøker med vin] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524041737/http://www.aftenposten.no/kul_und/article1181665.ece |date=May 24, 2011 }} {{no_icon}}</ref>
===''Vinforum''=== In 1986 Ronold and Ola Dybvik founded the publication ''Vinforum''.<ref name=aus/><ref name=vinforum1-2010>{{Cite journal| last = Dybvik| first = Ola | title = Verdens beste vinbutikk | journal = Vinforum | volume = 24 | issue = 1| pages = 18–21| date = January 2010 | language= Norwegian }}</ref> The magazine is annually published by Pedicel AS in five issues, in addition to six subscriber newsletters that are distributed digitally or as paper edition. Typically ca. 70 pages long, the magazine includes features, wine reviews and a column by [[Jancis Robinson]] MW translated into Norwegian.
The motivation behind founding the magazine was, according to a statement in a 2010 ''Vinforum'' editorial by Dybvik, because the Norwegian [[alcohol monopoly]] chain store [[Vinmonopolet]] "failed in its responsibility to its customers by practicing an arrogance with the inherent insolence of dictating the tastes of the Norwegian people. And worst of all, they managed to convince the Norwegian people they were doing a good job."<ref name=vinforum1-2010-leder>{{Cite journal| last = Dybvik| first = Ola | title = Heia Norge! | journal = Vinforum | volume = 24 | issue = 1| pages = 7| date = January 2010 | language= Norwegian }}</ref> At the time Vinmonopolet had an [[Italian wine]] selection which totalled 14 labels (including reds, whites and [[Sparkling wine|sparkling]]). This situation has since improved significantly over two decades, with Dybvik declaring in 2010, "we are living in paradise".<ref name=vinforum1-2010/>
In 2003 Ronold and ''Vinforum'' challenged the Norwegian ban on all advertisement of alcoholic drink, after the equivalent ban in Sweden had become overturned following actions by the magazine ''Gourmet'' and it had been demonstrated to oppose [[European Union|EU]] free trade rules. In June 2009 Norwegian supreme court ruled against Ronold and ''Vinforum'', leaving the Norwegian alcoholic advertisement ban intact.<ref>Vermes, Thomas, abcnyheter.no (November 11, 2008). [http://www.abcnyheter.no/node/77417 Lagretten stopper vinreklame] {{no_icon}}</ref><ref>Dalheim, Ulf, ''Addressavisen'' (June 26, 2009). [http://www.adressa.no/kultur/vin/article1343864.ece Vinforum tapte i Høyesterett] {{no_icon}}</ref>
In 2012, Ola Dybvig sold his 50% shares of ''Vinforum'' publisher Pedicel AS to the publishing house Forlagshuset Vigmostad og Bjørke, a previous publication collaborator, with Arno Vigmostad and Arnstein Bjørke as replacement partners to Arne Ronold.<ref>Bø, Merete, ''DN.no'' (September 27, 2012). [http://www.dn.no/vinguiden/article2462935.ece Eierskifte i Vinforum] {{no_icon}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Bruce Raymond Voeller | image = File:Voeller 2.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = May 12, 1934 | birth_place = [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | death_date = February 13, 1994 (age 59) | death_place = [[Topanga, California]] | nationality = [[American people|American]] | other_names = | occupation = Biologist, activist | years_active = 1970s-1994 | known_for = }} '''Bruce Raymond Voeller''' (May 12, 1934 – February 13, 1994) was a [[biologist]] and researcher, primarily in the field of [[AIDS]] and [[gay rights]] activist.
==Biography== Voeller was born in [[Minneapolis]] and raised in [[Oregon]].<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/24/obituaries/dr-bruce-voeller-is-dead-at-59-helped-lead-fight-against-aids.html |title=Dr. Bruce Voeller Is Dead at 59; Helped Lead Fight Against AIDS |first=Wolfgang |last=Saxon |date=1994-02-24 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-10-09}}</ref> When he was at school, he was assured by a school counselor that he was not homosexual, even though he had felt such feelings very early on.<ref name=stewart>{{cite book |title=Gay and Lesbian Issues |first=Chuck |last=Stewart |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2003 |isbn=1-85109-372-9 |pages=168–9}}</ref>
Voeller graduated with a bachelor's degree from [[Reed College]] in 1956.<ref name=stewart /> He was awarded a five-year fellowship to the [[Rockefeller University|Rockefeller Institute]],<ref name=nytimes /> and earned a [[Ph.D.]] in biology in 1961.<ref name=stewart /> He became an associate professor at the Institute in 1966. He wrote four books while there, as well as editing others' work, and writing numerous papers and articles. He married Kytja Scott Voeller,<ref name=nytimes /> whom he met at graduate school, and they had three children.<ref name=stewart />
He [[Coming out|came out]] at the age of 29,<ref name=nytimes /> and divorced from his wife in 1971. After becoming president of the New York [[Gay Activists Alliance]], he decided it was not wide enough in its coverage. Therefore, with some friends, he founded the [[National Gay and Lesbian Task Force|National Gay Task Force]] in October 1973, and was its director until 1978. The Task Force established affiliations with more than 2000 gay groups, and by 1978 had over 10,000 members.<ref name=stewart /> In 1977, the National Gay Task Force (now the [[National LGBTQ Task Force]]) successfully initiated the first-ever meeting between the White House and more than a dozen gay and lesbian leaders. President Jimmy Carter’s assistant, Midge Costanza, met with Task Force co-chairs and board members as well as representatives of gay and lesbian organizations for a briefing on critical policy issues affecting this constituency. The meeting marked the first time openly gay and lesbian leaders were welcomed at the White House and the first official discussion of gay and lesbian rights in the White House. Attendees at the White House meeting included: [[Frank Kameny]], Myra Keddell, Charles Brydon, Ray Hartman, Betty Powell, William Kelley,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glhalloffame.org/index.pl?item=9&todo=view_item|title=William B. Kelley|accessdate=2015-05-25}}</ref> [[Troy Perry]], [[Jean O'Leary]], [[Elaine Noble]], George Raya and Pokey Anderson.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/press/releases/prAPC_032207 |title=Today marks 30th anniversary of first-ever meeting between White House and gay leaders |publisher=TaskForce |date=2007-03-26 |accessdate=2013-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103014614/http://www.thetaskforce.org/press/releases/prAPC_032207 |archivedate=2013-11-03 |df= }}</ref> He also founded the Mariposa Foundation, which specializes in sex research, and sexually transmitted diseases.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bnl.gov/bera/activities/globe/bruce_voeller.htm |title=Bruce Voeller |publisher=bnl.gov |accessdate=2008-10-09}}</ref>
Before the 1980s, [[AIDS]] was known by various names, including GRIDD (Gay Related Immune Defense Disorder). Because this term was inaccurate, Voeller coined the term ''acquired immune deficiency syndrome''.<ref name=stewart /> His partner was Richard Lucik, who was also his associate at Mariposa. Voeller died in 1994 of an AIDS related illness in [[California]], at the age of 59.<ref name=nytimes />

{{no footnotes|date=May 2018}} [[File:Curonian king woman.jpg|thumb|Curonian king woman from Turlava parish in Kuldīga region wearing traditional clothing (1895)]] '''Curonian Kings''' ({{lang-de|Kurische Könige}}; {{lang-lv|kuršu ķoniņi}}) are a [[Latvian people|Latvian]] cultural group, originally lesser vassals and free farmers that lived in seven villages between [[Kuldīga|Goldingen (Kuldīga)]] and [[Aizpute|Hasenpoth (Aizpute)]] in [[Courland]].
It is unclear how Curonian Kings gained their status, however a popular assumption is that their ancestors were [[Curonians|Curonian]] [[nobility]] prior to conquest by [[Livonian Order]]. They were first mentioned in a document of 1320 and lived in the villages of [[Ķoniņciems]], [[Pliķu ciems]], [[Kalējciems]], [[Ziemeļciems]], [[Viesalgciems]], [[Sausgaļciems]], and [[Dragūnciems]] (now in [[Kuldīga municipality]]). All of them possessed independent farms (did not belong to any lord), but they were not allowed to own their own serfs. They had only one landlord [[komtur]] of Kuldīga and they were related to him only by military service in case of war. Curonians usually served as a [[light cavalry]] in the Livonian Order army. Sources mentions that Curonian Kings fought in the [[Livonian War]] against invading Russians, as Johann Renner's chronicle reports:
::''The Russians protected themselves boldly, and they knocked out a Curonian cadet (who, although only a peasant, is called by them the Curonian king) from his horse.
::—Johann Renner, Lievländische Historien, 1556–1561, C. 124v''
Curonian Kings also was allowed to practice some aspects of paganism during period of [[Livonian Confederation]]. Despite formal Christianisation after Livonian Crusade Curonian Kings owned a sacred forest where nobody was allowed to hunt or walk. It was used as a place of worship and for cremation of the dead. Hunt was allowed only once a year before Christmas but part of the game must be used as offering. Most likely those were Curonian Kings which was described by [[Guillebert de Lannoy]] in 1413 when he traveled from Konigsberg to Novgorod. He writes that there is a sect of curonians who still burns their dead in a sacred groves with garments and weapons with them. Part of this forest has survived until 21st century and local people still maintains it with great respect.
In 1504 master of the Livonian order [[Walter von Plettenberg]] awarded Curonian King Andrejs Peniķis, commander of curonian light cavalry for his loyal service during livonian wars with [[Muscovite Russia]].
It is known that in the 17th century Curonian Kings had their own [[coat of arms|coats of arms]]. In the [[Duchy of Courland and Semigallia]] they gradually lost their privileges, but they were still counted as separate class. They were not recognized landlords but maintained middle position between landlords and peasants. However, in 18th century they were likened to [[serfs]], although with smaller [[socage]] duties.
Their status was again recognized in 19th century, although they were not recognized as part of local nobility. In 1860 there were 833 Curonian kings living in [[Courland Governorate]]. While the Curonian tribe had long been assimilated by the Latvians, the Curonian Kings preserved a separate identity and traditions. Differences mandated by traditional rights disappeared as legal basis for them was removed in 1920s after Latvia became independent.
== Notable Curonian Kings == * [[Mārtiņš Peniķis]] (1874–1964) – Latvian general, commander in chief of Latvian Army from 1928 to 1934. * [[Ivars Tontegode]] (1983–) – Latvian film director. * [[Jānis Peniķis]] (1933–) – Latvian political scientist.

'''Darren Everett Criss''' (born February 5, 1987)<ref name=tvg>{{cite journal|title=Darren Criss profile|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/darren-criss-307244/bio|work=TVGuide.com|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}</ref> is an American actor, singer and songwriter. One of the founding members and co-owners of [[StarKid Productions]], a musical theater company based in [[Chicago]], Criss first garnered attention playing the lead role of [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]] in, and writing most of the music and lyrics for, StarKid's musical production of ''[[A Very Potter Musical]]''. The theater troupe made ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' history when their original album, ''[[Me and My Dick (soundtrack)|Me and My Dick]]'', became the first charting student-produced musical recording,{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} debuting at number eleven on the [[Billboard charts#Albums|Top Cast Albums]] chart in 2010. Criss has also starred on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in ''[[How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying (musical)|How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying]]'' and ''[[Hedwig and the Angry Inch (musical)|Hedwig and the Angry Inch]]''. In 2015, Criss co-founded Elsie Fest which is touted as "New York City’s first outdoor music festival celebrating tunes from the stage and screen".<ref>{{cite web|title=Elsie Fest|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elsie_Fest|website=Wikipedia|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=February 2018}}
Criss is best known for his portrayal of [[Blaine Anderson]] on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] [[musical film|musical]] [[comedy-drama]] series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''. Initially appearing as the lead vocalist of ''Glee''{{'}}s [[The Dalton Academy Warblers|Dalton Academy Warblers]], Criss' first number, a cover version of "[[Teenage Dream (Katy Perry song)|Teenage Dream]]", became the fastest-selling ''Glee'' single, reached number eight on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and was certified gold in the US. The Warblers have sold over 1.3 million tracks, and the soundtrack album, ''[[Glee: The Music Presents the Warblers]]'' (2011), peaked at number two on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. He was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]] in 2015 for writing the song "[[This Time (Glee song)|This Time]]" for the [[Dreams Come True (Glee)|''Glee'' finale]].
In March 2017, Criss debuted his indie pop band Computer Games along with his brother Chuck Criss. Their first album, ''Lost Boys Life'' EP features 4 songs written by the duo.<ref>{{cite web|title=Darren Criss & Brother Chuck Talk New, 'Unapologetically Fun' Alt-Pop Project, Computer Games|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7717175/darren-criss-computer-games-brother-chuck-lost-boys-life-interview|website=Billboard}}</ref> The lead single "Every Single Night" debuted at #2 on Billboard’s "Hot Singles".<ref>{{cite web|title=VIDEO: Darren Criss Performs 'I Dreamed A Dream' Live on TODAY|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/VIDEO-Darren-Criss-Performs-I-Dreamed-A-Dream-Live-on-TODAY-20170802|website=Broadway World|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> In December 2017, Criss released a 5-track solo EP titled ''Homework''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nobil|first1=Taryn|title=Darren Criss to Release ‘Homework’ EP, First Solo Project in Over Seven Years|url=https://variety.com/2017/music/news/darren-criss-homework-ep-1202625138/|website=Variety|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> The EP debuted #1 on Billboard's Heatseekers Chart<ref>{{cite web|title=Chart History|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/darren-criss/chart-history/heatseekers-albums|website=Billboard|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> and #7 on Billboard's Independent Albums Chart.<ref>{{cite web|title=Darren Criss Chart History|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/darren-criss|website=Billboard|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref>
In addition to his music endeavors, Criss starred in the second installment of Ryan Murphy’s ''[[American Crime Story]]''. Subtitled ''[[The Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story|The Assassination of Gianni Versace]]'' (2018)<ref>{{cite web|title=THE ASSASSINATION OF GIANNI VERSACE: AMERICAN CRIME STORY|url=http://www.fxnetworks.com/shows/american-crime-story/cast-crew/darren-criss-andrew-cunanan|website=FX|accessdate=January 6, 2018}}</ref>, Criss's portrayal of [[spree killer]] [[Andrew Cunanan]] received acclaim from critics, and earned him an Emmy win for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or Movie|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or Movie]].
==Early life and education== Criss was born in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], the youngest child of Cerina and Charles William Criss, an investment banker and a patron of the arts.<ref name=tvg/><ref name=interviewmagazine>{{cite web|last1= Petrarca|first1=Emilia|title=Exclusive Video Premiere: 'Will I See You Again,' Chuck Criss|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/exclusive-video-premiere-will-i-see-you-again-chuck-criss/#_|work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]]|accessdate=March 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130723221132/http://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/exclusive-video-premiere-will-i-see-you-again-chuck-criss|archivedate=July 23, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Henderson|first1=Kathy|title=Darren Criss and his Dream-Come-True Broadway Return in Hedwig and the Angry Inch|url=http://broadwaydirect.com/feature/darren-criss-hedwig|website= Broadway Direct| accessdate=April 22, 2015}}</ref><ref name="teddywing.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.teddywing.com/projects/philharmonia/board/ccriss.html|title= Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra: C. William Criss, Chair, Development Committee Cornerstone Campaign Committee|publisher= Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra |via= TeddyWing.com| accessdate=September 27, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907202333/http://www.teddywing.com/projects/philharmonia/board/ccriss.html| archivedate=September 7, 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref> He has an older brother, Charles "Chuck" Criss, who is a member of the band [[Freelance Whales]].<ref name= interviewmagazine />
Criss is [[Eurasian (mixed ancestry)|Eurasian]] – his mother is a native of [[Cebu City|Cebu]], [[Philippines]], while his father, a native of [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], is of English, German, and Irish descent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glee star Darren Criss visits his mom's homeland, the Philippines!|url=http://www.zeibiz.com/2010/12/glee-star-darren-criss-visits-his-moms-homeland-the-philippines123|website= Zeibiz.com|accessdate=April 22, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718025806/http://www.zeibiz.com/2010/12/glee-star-darren-criss-visits-his-moms-homeland-the-philippines123/|archivedate=July 18, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Criss was raised primarily in San Francisco, apart from 1988–92, when the family resided in [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]], where Charles Criss started EastWest Bank, serving as Chairman and CEO.<ref name="teddywing.com"/>
Criss attended Roman Catholic schools. He completed his elementary education at [[Stuart Hall for Boys]], and later graduated from [[Saint Ignatius College Preparatory]] in 2005.<ref name="sacredsf30371">{{cite web|url=http://z5.sacredsf.org/~broadview/?p=3037|last=Kloepfer|first=Sara|title=Darren Criss, former Stuart Hall for Boys student, finds role on 'Glee{{'-}}|publisher=The Broadview|date=December 12, 2010|accessdate=October 15, 2011}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=Rfl0216 |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In 2009, Criss obtained his [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] from the [[University of Michigan]], majoring in Theater Performance and minoring in Musicology and Italian.<ref name="sacredsf3037"/><ref name="Billboard Magazine">{{cite web|title=Darren Criss Billboard Live Q&A Pt 2|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SqND3dJATi4&feature=youtube_gdata_player|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=March 18, 2012}}</ref>

==Career== ===Theater=== [[File:Darren criss on Hedwig and the angry inch.PNG|thumb|Criss during ''[[Hedwig and the Angry Inch (musical)|Hedwig and the Angry Inch]]'']]
====Debut==== Criss made his professional stage debut at the age of ten as Cesario in [[42nd Street Moon]]'s production of ''[[Fanny (musical)|Fanny]]'' (1997), then played Mauro in the [[Richard Rodgers]] and [[Stephen Sondheim]] musical ''[[Do I Hear a Waltz?]]'' (1998), and Beauregard Calhoun in ''[[Babes in Arms]]'' (1999).<ref name="Fanny">{{cite news|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-01-04/entertainment/26357986_1_summer-camp-chris-colfer-glee|work=The San Francisco Chronicle|first=Regan|last=McMahon|title=Day in Pictures, December 26, 2000|date=January 4, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Waltz">{{cite web|url=http://www.42ndstmoon.com/Schedule/waltz.html|title=Do I Hear a Waltz? |publisher=42ndstmoon.com|accessdate=March 1, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Babes">{{cite web|url=http://www.42ndstmoon.com/Schedule/babesinarms.html|title=Babes in Arms|publisher=42ndstmoon.com|accessdate=March 1, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707064106/http://www.42ndstmoon.com/Schedule/babesinarms.html|archivedate=July 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Throughout his adolescence, Criss appeared in a number of the [[American Conservatory Theater]]'s plays, notably ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'', ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', and ''[[The Voysey Inheritance]]''.<ref name="blogspot1">{{cite web|last=Levin |first=Ken |url=http://42ndstreetmoon.blogspot.com/2010/12/gleeful-experience-with-babes-in-arms.html|title=42ND STREET MOON: A Glee – ful experience with Babes in Arms|publisher=42ndstreetmoon.blogspot.com|date=December 16, 2010|accessdate=September 27, 2011}}</ref> At the [[University of Michigan]], he performed in stage productions such as ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'', ''[[A Few Good Men (play)|A Few Good Men]]'', and ''[[The Cripple of Inishmaan]]''.<ref name="sacredsf3037"/>
====StarKid Productions==== Upon receiving his [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] in 2009, Criss, along with some friends and classmates from the [[University of Michigan]], co-founded [[StarKid Productions]], a musical theater company. His most prominent acting role with [[StarKid Productions|StarKid]] has been that of [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]] in the musical comedies ''[[A Very Potter Musical]]'', ''[[A Very Potter Sequel]]'', and ''[[A Very Potter Senior Year]]'' (based on the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' series of novels by [[J.K. Rowling]]).<ref>{{cite web|last=Shekhar Pandey|first=Kavi|title=The StarKids Are All Right: The rise of a 'U' theater troupe from the Basement to the national stage|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/arts/starkid|publisher=[[The Michigan Daily]]|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=November 8, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Shows|url=http://teamstarkid.com/shows.html|publisher=StarKid Productions|accessdate=March 7, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226044309/http://www.teamstarkid.com/shows.html|archivedate=February 26, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
====Broadway==== In January 2012, Criss made his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut, replacing [[Daniel Radcliffe]] in the role of J. Pierrepont Finch in the revival of ''[[How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying]]'' for a three-week engagement at the [[Al Hirschfeld Theatre]].<ref name="broadway1">{{cite web|title=Glee Star Darren Criss Begins Run in 'How To Succeed in Business Without Really Trying' |url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/how-succeed-business-without-really-trying/buzz/159171/glee-star-darren-criss-begins-run-in-how-to-succeed-in-business-without-really-trying/|publisher=Broadway.com|accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref> His stint there proved to be a success: apart from Daniel Radcliffe's final week, the musical had the three most lucrative weeks of its 11-month run with Criss in the lead role, grossing more than four million dollars.<ref>{{cite web|last=Geier|first=Thom|title=Darren Criss becomes Broadway's $4 million man|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2012/01/23/darren-criss-becomes-broadways-4-million-man/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=January 27, 2012}}</ref>
Criss took on the role of Hedwig in ''[[Hedwig and the Angry Inch (musical)|Hedwig and the Angry Inch]]'' from April 29, 2015, to July 19, 2015, at the [[Belasco Theater]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Snetiker|first1=Marc|title=Darren Criss Will Return to Broadway as the Next Hedwig|url=http://time.com/3712431/darren-criss-hedge|website=Time.com|publisher=Time Magazine|accessdate=February 18, 2015|date=February 17, 2015}}</ref> He headlined the national tour in San Francisco and Los Angeles, from October 2 to November 27, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/legit/news/darren-criss-hedwig-tour-1201769110/|title=Darren Criss to Star in National Tour of ‘Hedwig and the Angry Inch’|last=Cox|first=Gordon|date=2016-05-09|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-27}}</ref>
===Television=== [[File:Dalton Academy Warblers.png|thumb|Criss as Blaine Anderson with The Dalton Academy Warblers]]
====Debut==== Criss started his television career with a five-episode arc playing the character of Josh Burton on ''[[Eastwick (TV series)|Eastwick]]'' in 2009. The following year, he appeared in an episode of the series ''[[Cold Case (TV series)|Cold Case]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Imogene, Starring Darren Criss & Kristen Wiig, Gets U.S. Distribution|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/163925/imogene-starring-darren-criss-kristen-wiig-gets-us-distribution|publisher=Broadway.com|accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref>
====''Glee'' (2010–2015)==== Criss portrayed [[Blaine Anderson]], on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] television series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox.com/glee/bios/darren-criss|title=FOX Broadcasting Company – Glee – Bios|publisher=Fox.com|accessdate=September 27, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924153753/http://www.fox.com/glee/bios/darren-criss/|archivedate=September 24, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He made his first appearance in [[Glee (season 2)|season two]] in the episode "[[Never Been Kissed (Glee)|Never Been Kissed]]", which aired on November 9, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20017760-10391698.html|title= Darren Criss Joins "Glee" Cast|author=Derschowitz, Jessica|work=CBSnews.com|date=September 27, 2010|accessdate=October 4, 2010}}</ref>
Blaine attended Dalton Academy and was lead singer of its glee club, [[The Dalton Academy Warblers]]. Blaine initially served as a friend and mentor for Kurt, the bullied gay member of the Warblers' rival glee club, New Directions. Chemistry between the two characters, combined with fan support for the potential couple, led series co-creator [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] to pair them romantically onscreen. At the beginning of the [[Glee (season 3)|third season]], Blaine transfers to McKinley High and joins New Directions; concurrently, Criss was promoted from recurring guest star to the show's main cast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2011/09/glee-recap-back-to-school-and-basics-in-the-season-3-premiere.html|title={{-'}}Glee' recap: Back to school (and basics) in the Season 3 premiere|first=Amy|last=Reiter|work=Los Angeles Times|date=September 21, 2011|accessdate=September 21, 2011}}</ref>
In the subsequent seasons, Blaine goes off to college and later returns to Dalton to become the vocal director of the Warblers. In the final season, he marries his long-time love, Kurt. Discussing public response to his character, Criss stated that he particularly enjoyed comments from "people from parts of the world who are maybe not as exposed to certain ideologies", but had reconsidered their stance on relationships and human rights as a result of the Blaine and Kurt storyline. He called this response "phenomenal" and said, "I was a straight kid growing up in a very gay community and it's something that I've had to watch so many friends have to struggle with and have no place to go to identify in kind of a grander media culture. To be a small piece of that machine is incredibly wonderful."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afterelton.com/people/2011/01/darren-criss-glee-teenage-dream?page=0%2C1|title=Interview: Darren Criss Humbly Calls Himself "Last Grain of Sand"|last=Jensen|first=Michael|date=January 18, 2011|work=[[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterElton.com]]|publisher=[[Logo (TV channel)|Logo]]|accessdate=April 15, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123164022/http://www.afterelton.com/people/2011/01/darren-criss-glee-teenage-dream?page=0%2C1|archivedate=January 23, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
He was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]] for writing the song "[[This Time (Glee song)|This Time]]" one in a handful of the show’s original songs over its six season run, for the ''Glee'' finale, “[[Dreams Come True (Glee)|Dreams Come True]]”.
====Career post-''Glee''==== In 2017, Criss reunited with ''Glee'' creator [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] to portray serial killer [[Andrew Cunanan]] in the [[The Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story|second season]] of Murphy's anthology series ''[[American Crime Story]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/02/edgar-ramirez-darren-criss-star-versace-american-crime-story-fx-1201913309/|title=Edgar Ramirez & Darren Criss To Star In 'Versace: American Crime Story' On FX|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=February 15, 2017|accessdate=February 16, 2017}}</ref> His performance received acclaim from critics, and earned Criss an [[Primetime Emmy Award|Emmy]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or Movie|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or Movie]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/american_crime_story/s02|title=American Crime Story: The Assassination of Gianni Versace (2018) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=July 16, 2018}}</ref>
===Film debut=== [[File:Girl Most Likely 33.jpg|thumb|Criss signing autographs during the premiere of ''[[Girl Most Likely]]'']] On September 7, 2012, Criss made his feature film debut in the comedy ''[[Girl Most Likely]]''. It premiered at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] (TIFF) and was released nationwide on July 19, 2013. Previously titled ''Imogene'', the film starred [[Kristen Wiig]], [[Annette Bening]], and [[Matt Dillon]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Bahr|first=Lindsey|title=Kristen Wiig comedy 'Girl Most Likely' gets July release date|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/12/20/kristen-wiig-comedy|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=December 24, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Young|first=Deborah|title=Imogene: Toronto Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/imogene-toronto-film-review-368819|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=February 3, 2013|date=September 7, 2012}}</ref>
===Music=== ====Solo artist (2005–present)==== Criss began his solo music career while attending the [[University of Michigan]]. Playing in small venues, he developed his own musical repertoire which today consists of standards from the [[Great American Songbook]], contemporary songs, Disney songs, and his own compositions.<ref>{{cite news|last=Donahue|first=Ann|title=Darren Criss crosses over|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/20/us-darrencriss-idUSTRE6AJ01M20101120|agency=Reuters|accessdate=February 18, 2012|date=November 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Herrera|first=Monica|title=Glee's Darren Criss: The Billboard Cover Story|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/472045/glees-darren-criss-the-billboard-cover-story|work=Billboard Magazine|accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref>
On July 20, 2010, Criss released an independently-produced [[Extended play|EP]] called ''[[Human (EP)|Human]]''.<ref name="iTunes">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/human/id382660889|title=Human by Darren Criss}}</ref> Describing his album as "soul-folk" to ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', it peaked at No. 17 on the [[Top Heatseekers|''Billboard'' Top Heatseekers Albums]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Grady|title='A Very Potter Musical' star Darren Criss talks about his new EP and the future for Team StarKid|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2010/07/30/a-very-potter-musical-star-darren-criss-talks-about-his-new-ep-and-the-future-for-team-starkid|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=January 31, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Donahue|first=Ann|title=Darren Criss Crosses Over|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/20/us-darrencriss-idUSTRE6AJ01M20101120|agency=Reuters|accessdate=January 28, 2013|date=November 20, 2010}}</ref> On December 10, 2010, Criss became the 400,000th member of the [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers]] (ASCAP).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/playback/2010/12/new_member/Criss.aspx|title=Hot Glee Star and New ASCAP Member Darren Criss Talks Songwriting and Performs a Holiday Classic|publisher=Ascap.com|date=December 20, 2010|accessdate=September 27, 2011}}</ref> In April 2011, he signed with [[Sony Music Entertainment]].<ref name="Sony">{{cite web|last=Lawrence|first=Hannah|title={{-'}}Glee's Darren Criss Signs Record Deal with Sony|publisher=HollywoodNews|date=April 18, 2011|url=http://www.hollywood.com/news/Glees_Darren_Criss_Signs_Record_Deal_with_Sony/7784826|accessdate=June 20, 2011}}</ref> He is in the process of recording a full-length studio album, with a release date yet to be determined.<ref>{{cite news|last=Halperin|first=Shirley|title=Ron Fair's Next Moves: A&R Gig on 'The Voice'; Front Line Management Consultancy; Darren Criss Album|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/07/18/darren-criss-recording-new-music_n_901461.html|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=March 14, 2013|date=July 18, 2011}}</ref>
In January 2013, Criss performed for [[Barack Obama|US President Barack Obama]], [[Michelle Obama|First Lady Michelle Obama]], and [[Joe Biden|Vice President Joe Biden]] at the [[United States presidential inaugural balls|inaugural balls]] of the [[Second inauguration of Barack Obama|57th Presidential Inauguration]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Darren rehearses before Kid's Inaugural Concert|url=http://darrencriss.snappages.com/blog/2013/01/19/darren-rehearses-before-kids-inaugural-concert|publisher=Darren Criss Official Website|accessdate=March 14, 2013}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=Rfl0216 |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cooper|first=Rachel|title=Inaugural Balls 2013 - A Guide to Inaugural Balls and Galas|url=http://dc.about.com/od/specialevents/a/inauguralballs.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=March 14, 2013}}</ref>
During a benefit concert for public school arts on April 14, 2013, Criss was made an honorary member of [[Yale University]]'s a cappella singing group [[The Whiffenpoofs]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Parker|first=Valerie|title=Darren Criss – Teenage Dream, Rainbow Connection, and the Whiffenpoof Alumni Song|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3H-sEAalj8U|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Darren performs with the Yale Whiffenpoofs at PS Arts Benefit Concert|url=http://darrencriss.snappages.com/blog/2013/04/16/darren-performs-with-the-yale-whiffenpoofs-at-ps-arts-benefit-concert|publisher=Darren Criss Official Website|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=Rfl0216 |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Criss' first solo music tour visited 17 cities in the United States, Canada, and France from May 29–June 30, 2013, and included songs from ''Glee'', StarKid, his ''Human'' EP, and new material from his upcoming solo album.<ref name="Goldberg">{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|title='Glee's' Darren Criss Sets Summer Concert Tour|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/glees-darren-criss-sets-summer-444666|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=April 23, 2013|date=April 23, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Darren Criss en concert le 17 Juin">{{cite web|title=Darren Criss en concert le 17 Juin|url=https://mobile.twitter.com/LivenationFR/status/336759049968295937/photo/1|publisher=Live Nation France|accessdate=May 21, 2013}}</ref>
====StarKid Productions (2009–present)==== Criss is credited as one of the primary songwriters and composers for [[StarKid Productions]]. He has contributed songs to ''[[A Very Potter Musical (soundtrack)|A Very Potter Musical]]'', ''[[Me and My Dick (soundtrack)|Me and My Dick]]'' (which became the first-ever student-produced college musical to reach ''[[Billboard charts|Billboard]]'', debuting at No. 11 on the Top Cast Albums chart), [[StarKid Productions#Web series|''Little White Lie'']], and ''[[A Very Potter Senior Year]]''. Subsequently, Criss solely composed all the songs and music for ''[[A Very Potter Sequel (soundtrack)|A Very Potter Sequel]]'', its companion album ''[[A Very StarKid Album]]'', and ''[[Starship (soundtrack)|Starship]]'', which landed at No. 1 on the ''Billboard'' Top Cast Albums chart, and at No. 134 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|title=Adele's '21' Marks Sixth Week at No. 1 on Billboard 200|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/471739/adeles-21-marks-sixth-week-at-no-1-on-billboard-200|publisher=Billboard Magazine|accessdate=May 4, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Music|url=http://www.teamstarkid.com/music.html|publisher=StarKid Productions|accessdate=March 7, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302013720/http://teamstarkid.com/music.html|archivedate=March 2, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|title='My Dick' Rises To Become First Charting Student Musical|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/958920/my-dick-rises-to-become-first-charting-student-musical|publisher=Billboard Magazine|accessdate=May 21, 2013}}</ref>
In November 2011, Criss participated in [[StarKid Productions|StarKid]]'s first national concert tour, [[The SPACE Tour]], for the New York and Boston shows, and, in the summer of 2012, he joined them again for their second national tour, [[Apocalyptour]], for the Los Angeles and New York shows.<ref>{{cite web|last=Votta|first=Rae|title=Inside Darren Criss' Team StarKid: From 'A Very Potter Musical' to SPACE Tour|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/464956/inside-darren-criss-team-starkid-from-a-very-potter-musical-to-space-tour|work=Billboard Magazine|accessdate=November 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Votta|first=Rae|title=Day in the Life: Team StarKid (Featuring Darren Criss)|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/485436/day-in-the-life-team-starkid-featuring-darren-criss|publisher=Billboard Magazine|accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref>
====''Glee'' (2010–2015)==== [[File:Blaine Glee Tour Raise.jpg|thumb|left|Criss performing as [[Blaine Anderson]]]] As Blaine, Criss features in many musical performances on ''Glee'', which have been released as [[Single (music)|singles]], available for [[Music download|download]]. His first performance, "[[Teenage Dream (Katy Perry song)|Teenage Dream]]" by [[Katy Perry]], was featured on the soundtrack album ''[[Glee: The Music, Volume 4]]''.<ref name="vol4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2010/11/03/glee-the-music-volume-4-track-listing-released/|title={{-'}}Glee: The Music, Volume 4' Track listing Released|date=November 3, 2010|first=Jean|last=Bentley|work=TV Squad|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=November 3, 2010}}</ref> It reached number eight on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in the week ending November 27, 2010,<ref name="bill20101127">{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2010-11-27/hot-100?order=gainer|title=Hot 100: Week of November 27, 2010 (Biggest Jump)|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=March 23, 2011}}</ref> and number one on the Billboard Digital Songs chart.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20023393-10391698.html|work=CBS News|first=Joyce|last=Lee|title="Glee" Hits No. 1 on Charts with "Teenage Dream" Cover|date=November 19, 2010}}</ref>
It was the best-selling song in the US that week, selling 214,000 copies, the largest figure for a ''Glee'' title.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20023393-10391698.html|work=CBS News|first=Joyce|last=Lee|title="Glee" Hits No.1 on Charts with "Teenage Dream" Cover|date=November 19, 2010}}</ref> It was only the second US-certified gold single in the show's history.<ref name="riaa">{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Glee&format=&go=Search&perPage=50 |title=RIAA Gold & Platinum |publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |accessdate=July 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225031458/http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |archivedate=February 25, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> Both ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'s}} Jillian Mapes and Erica Futterman of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' deemed "Teenage Dream" the best song of "Never Been Kissed", the episode in which it featured.<ref name="JM">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/viral-videos/951288/glee-cast-shines-with-katy-perrys-teenage-dream|title={{-'}}Glee' Cast Shines With Katy Perry's 'Teenage Dream{{'-}}|date=November 10, 2010|first=Jillian|last=Mapes|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}</ref><ref name="EF">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/glee-playback-chris-colfer-outshines-the-music-in-never-been-kissed-20101110|title={{-'}}Glee' Playback: Chris Colfer Outshines the Music in 'Never Been Kissed{{'-}}|date=November 10, 2010|first=Erica|last=Futterman|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}</ref>
The ''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]''{{'s}} Anthony Benigno gave the song an "A", and noted that it was "flawless" and improved on Perry's original.<ref name="AB">{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2010/11/10/2010-11-10_glee_recap_never_been_kissed_introduces_darren_criss_and_gives_dot_jones_her_fir.html|title={{-'}}Glee' recap: 'Never Been Kissed' introduces Darren Criss and gives Dot Jones her first kiss|date=November 10, 2010|first=Anthony|last=Benigno|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}</ref> The performance was nominated for the Best Gay Moment of the Year and Favorite Music Video awards at the 2010 ''[[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterElton.com]]'' Visibility Awards.<ref name="AEV">{{cite web|url=http://www.afterelton.com/poll/2010/visibility-awards-winners|title=The AfterElton.com 2010 Visibility Awards – Winners|last=AfterElton.com Staff|date=December 20, 2010|work=[[AfterEllen.com and AfterElton.com|AfterElton.com]]|publisher=[[Logo (TV channel)|Logo]]|accessdate=January 2, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101065917/http://www.afterelton.com//poll//2010//visibility-awards-winners|archivedate=January 1, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A ''Billboard'' cover-feature on Criss noted that the performance "arguably ushered in the trend of more current pop hits being reworked by the [''Glee''] cast."<ref name="MH">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/472045/glees-darren-criss-the-billboard-cover-story|title={{-'}}Glee's' Darren Criss: The Billboard Cover Story|last=Herrera|first=Monica|date=April 15, 2011|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=April 21, 2011}}</ref>
Later songs performed by Blaine and the Warblers became popular enough to warrant a Warbler soundtrack album, ''[[Glee: The Music Presents the Warblers]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/08/glees-dalton-warblers-to-release-their-very-own-album/|title=''Glee''{{'s}} Dalton Warblers to Release Their Very Own Album|date=March 8, 2011|first=Elizabeth|last=Tyler|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=March 23, 2011}}</ref> It debuted at No. 2 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and No. 1 on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'s}} Soundtracks chart, selling 86,000 copies in its first week.<ref name="albumflies">{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/471856/glee-warblers-album-flies-high-on-billboard-200|title={{-'}}Glee' Warblers Album Flies High on Billboard 200|date=April 27, 2011|first=Keith|last=Caulfield|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|location=Los Angeles|accessdate=April 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2011-05-07/soundtracks|title=Soundtracks: Week of May 7, 2011|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=April 30, 2011}}</ref> The Warbler tracks had sold over 1.3 million copies as singles by the time the album was released.<ref name="holly">{{Cite web|url=http://hollywoodcrush.mtv.com/2011/03/23/glee-warblers-album|title={{-'}}Glee' News: Warblers Album Tracklisting And Artwork Revealed!|date=March 23, 2011|first=James|last=Dinh|publisher=MTV|accessdate=March 23, 2011}}</ref>
From May 21–July 3, 2011, Criss and the cast of ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' performed in [[Glee Live! In Concert!]], touring the US, Canada, England, and Ireland. According to ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', it was the 16th most successful concert tour of 2011, grossing more than $40 million, with total attendance topping 485,000. All 40 dates sold out, including shows at [[Staples Center]], [[Nassau Coliseum]], and [[The O2 Arena (London)|The O<sub>2</sub> Arenas]] in London and Dublin.<ref name="darrencriss.snappages.com">{{cite web|url=http://darrencriss.snappages.com/shows.htm|title=Darren Criss – Shows|publisher=Darrencriss.snappages.com|date=February 11, 2011|accessdate=September 27, 2011}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=Rfl0216 |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="25 Top Tours of 2011">{{cite web|title=25 Top Tours of 2011|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/42159/top-25-tours-of-2011|work=Billboard |accessdate=February 18, 2012}}</ref>
For Season 6 of ''Glee'', Criss composed "Rise" for the episode "[[The Rise and Fall of Sue Sylvester]]" and "[[This Time (Glee song)|This Time]]" for the [[Dreams Come True (Glee)|series finale]].<ref name="A Glee Star Wrote an Original Song for the Show">{{cite web|url=http://www.glamour.com/entertainment/blogs/obsessed/2015/03/darren-criss-rise-glee|title=A Glee Star Wrote an Original Song for the Shows|publisher=Glamour|date=March 2, 2015|accessdate=March 23, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Lea Michele's last Glee solo, written by Darren Criss">{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/03/16/lea-michele-darren-criss-last-song-glee-series-finale|title=Lea Michele's last Glee solo, written by Darren Criss|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=March 23, 2015}}</ref> Criss was nominated for a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Original Music and Lyrics]] for writing "This Time".<ref name="billboard emmy"/>
