===Lauren Platt=== {{main|Lauren Platt}} '''Lauren Platt''' (born 7 October 1997) is a former student from [[Essex]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theenquirer.co.uk/lauren-platt-x-factor-dad-backs-dream/|title=EXCLUSIVE: "She's wanted this since she was eight-years-old" – Lauren Platt's dad backs teenager's X Factor dream|last=Norris|first=Michelle|date=4 September 2014|work=[[National Enquirer]]|publisher=[[American Media]]|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> In 2010, she auditioned for the role of [[Louise Mitchell]] on ''[[EastEnders]]'', but lost out to Brittany Papple.<ref name="before the show">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s103/the-x-factor/feature/a601544/x-factor-finalists-what-did-the-contestants-do-before-the-show.html|title=X Factor finalists: What did the contestants do before the show?|last=Gordon|first=Naomi|date=6 October 2014|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref>
Platt was the youngest solo contestant in the competition and was mentored by [[Cheryl Fernandez-Versini]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reveal.co.uk/showbiz-celeb-gossip/news/a601906/x-factors-lauren-platt-flashes-a-smile-heading-to-live-show-rehearsals.html|title=X Factor's Lauren Platt flashes a smile heading to live show rehearsals|last=Storey|first=Katie|date=7 October 2014|work=Reveal|publisher=[[Nat Mags]]|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> With the eliminations of Stephanie Nala and Chloe Jasmine in week two and Lola Saunders in week four, Platt was Fernandez-Versini's last remaining act in the competition. In the quarter-final, Platt was in the bottom two with Stereo Kicks but was sent through to the semi-final after the result went to deadlock with [[Louis Walsh]] and [[Mel B]] voting to send Stereo Kicks through to the semi-final while Fernandez-Versini and [[Simon Cowell]] voting to send Platt through to the semi-final.<ref name="Result 8">''The X Factor'', UK series 11, week 8</ref> In the semi-final, she was in the bottom two with Andrea Faustini and was eliminated after only Fernandez-Versini voted to send Platt through to the final. After the series finished, voting statistics revealed that Platt received more votes than Faustini meaning if there wasn't a Final Showdown or if Walsh and/or Cowell voted to send Platt through to the final or if the result went to deadlock, Platt would've been sent through to the final and Faustini would've been eliminated.<ref name="Result 9"/> Her brother then auditioned as part of the dance group Entity Allstars for ''[[Britain's Got Talent (series 9)|Britain's Got Talent]]'' and got the golden buzzer from [[Alesha Dixon]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-05-09/alesha-dixon-hits-bgt-golden-buzzer-for-entity-allstars|title=Alesha Dixon hits BGT Golden Buzzer for Entity Allstars|last=Daly|first=Emma|date=9 May 2015|work=[[Radio Times]]|publisher=[[Immediate Media Company]]|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref>

===Lola Saunders=== '''Lola Belle Saunders''' (born 22 May 1994) is a fishmonger from [[East Boldon]], [[South Tyneside]]. She was not initially through to the live shows, but Walsh brought her back as the Girls' wildcard.<ref name="wildcards"/>

==Over 25s== The 'Over 25s' category was mentored by Simon Cowell. Contestants in the category are soloists over the age of 25. The six candidates at judges' houses were: Fleur East, Helen Fulthorpe, Ben Haenow, Jay James, [[Lizzy Pattinson]], and Stevi Ritchie. Cowell chose:
===Fleur East=== {{main|Fleur East}} '''Fleur East''' (born 29 October 1987, aged 29)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/TheXFactor/photos/a.167882313301.119173.79294403301/10152450127318302/|title=Massive happy birthday wishes, Fleur East!|date=29 October 2014|publisher=[[Facebook]]|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref> is a singer and fitness model from [[Walthamstow]]. She is of Ghanaian and British descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wathletic.com/fleur-east/small|title=Model/ Sport Profile - W Athletic|author=Anton|publisher=wathletic.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205080815/http://www.wathletic.com/fleur-east/small|archivedate=5 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/x-factor-hopeful-fleur-east-4596597|title=X Factor hopeful Fleur East tells how racist bullies made her life hell|last=Buxton|first=Olivia|date=9 November 2014|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> In 2005, she was on the [[The X Factor (UK series 2)|second series]] of the show as a member of the girl group [[Addictiv Ladies]]. The group were eliminated during the first week after ending up in the bottom two with [[Chico Slimani|Chico]].
In the final, East was announced as the runner-up in the competition, losing to fellow over-25 Ben Haenow with 34.3% of the votes to Haenow's 57.2%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/x-factor/11291141/x-factor-2014-final-results-winner-Fleur-East-Ben-Haenow-live.html|title=Ben Haenow wins The X Factor 2014: as it happened - Telegraph|date=15 December 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>

===Ben Haenow=== {{main|Ben Haenow}} '''Ben Bernard Haenow''' (born 6 January 1985, aged 31) is a van driver from [[Croydon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/Croydon-van-driver-Ben-Haenow-set-perform-place-X/story-23043532-detail/story.html |title=Croydon van driver Ben Haenow set to perform for a place in X Factor live shows |date=4 October 2014 |work=[[The Croydon Advertiser]] |publisher=[[Local World]] |accessdate=5 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006065749/http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/Croydon-van-driver-Ben-Haenow-set-perform-place-X/story-23043532-detail/story.html |archivedate=6 October 2014 |df= }}</ref> He has sung in bands since he was 15 and formed the [[rock and roll]] band the Lost Audio with his brother Alex in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/Croydon-X-Factor-Ben-Haenow-tells-surreal/story-22902866-detail/story.html |title=Croydon X Factor Ben Haenow tells of his 'surreal' experience performing at Wembley |work=[[The Croydon Advertiser]] |publisher=[[Local World]] |accessdate=15 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007071722/http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/Croydon-X-Factor-Ben-Haenow-tells-surreal/story-22902866-detail/story.html |archivedate=7 October 2014 |df= }}</ref>
In week 10, it was announced that Haenow was the winner, beating fellow Over 25 Fleur East with 57.2% of the votes. His debut single "[[Something I Need#Ben Haenow version|Something I Need]]" was released after his victory and became the [[List of UK Singles Chart Christmas number ones|Christmas number one]].

===Jay James=== '''Jay James''' (born '''Jay James Picton''' in 1983, aged 33)<ref name="Saundersfoot">{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/x-factors-welsh-contenders-come-7882009|title=X Factor's Welsh contenders come a cropper at Simon Cowell's house|last=McCrum|first=Kirstie|date=4 October 2014|work=[[Western Mail (Wales)|Western Mail]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> is a former [[Royal Navy]] fitness instructor from [[Saundersfoot]], in [[Pembrokeshire]].<ref name="Saundersfoot" /> He already had a record deal prior to the show and released his debut album ''[[Play It by Heart]]'' through [[Decca Records]] in 2012.<ref name="before the show" /> The same year, he featured on the song "Fly" by Cinematic, released on [[Black Butter Records]] (home to [[Rudimental]], [[Gorgon City]] and [[Clean Bandit]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earmilk.com/2012/03/27/cinematic-fly-feat-jay-james-picton-video/|title=Cinematic - "Fly" (Feat. Jay James Picton) (Video)|publisher=Earmilk|date=27 March 2012}}</ref>
James was in the bottom two with Paul Akister in week 5, but he was saved after Walsh sent the vote to deadlock and Akister was eliminated as the contestant with fewest number of public votes.<ref name="Result 5"/> However, the following week, James was in the bottom two with Stevi Richie. The vote again went to deadlock, and James was voted out due to having the fewest public votes. He finished in 8th place. He was given a place in the X Factor Live Tour for coming in the top half, and anybody eliminated after him was in the X Factor Live Tour as well.<ref name="Result 6"/>

===Stevi Ritchie=== {{Main|Stevi Ritchie}} '''Stevie "Stevi" Ritchie''' (born '''Steven Ritchie'''; 17 September 1980, aged 36) is from [[Colchester]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/09/02/x-factor-2014-contestant-stevi-ritchie-changes-name-so-he-doesnt-get-confused-with-porn-star-4854084/|title=X Factor 2014: Contestant Stevi Ritchie changes name to stop confusion with porn star|last=Baillie|first=Katie|date=2 September 2014|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|publisher=[[DMG Media]]|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref> He was not initially through to the live shows, but Fernandez-Versini brought him back as the Over 25s' wildcard.<ref name="wildcards"/>
After the eliminations of Overload Generation in week 1 and Jack Walton and Lola Saunders in week 4, Ritchie was the last wildcard left in the competition. In week 6, Ritchie found himself in the bottom two with fellow Over 25 Jay James. His mentor Cowell and Walsh opted to send him home, but Mel B and Fernandez-Versini, who picked him as the wildcard act and had the deciding vote, opted to send James home, resulting in Ritchie being saved after the result went to deadlock.<ref name="Result 6">''The X Factor'', UK series 11, week 6</ref> The following week, he was in the bottom two again with Andrea Faustini and was eliminated by the judges with only his mentor Cowell voting to send Ritchie through to the quarter-final and Mel B, Fernandez-Versini and Walsh voting to send Faustini through to the quarter-final. However voting statistics confirmed that Ritchie had actually received more votes than Faustini, meaning if Walsh sent the vote to deadlock, Ritchie would have been sent through to the quarter-final and Faustini would have been eliminated.<ref name="Result 7 part 2">''The X Factor'', UK series 11, week 7</ref>
Following the X Factor Stevi participated in Celebrity Big Brother for England, where she came 5th with girlfriend Chloe-Jasmine.

==Groups== The 'Groups' category was mentored by Louis Walsh. Contestants in this category are either duos or vocal harmony groups, all aged 16 and over. The six candidates at judges' houses were: Blonde Electra, Concept, New Boy Band, New Girl Group, Only The Young, and The Brooks. Walsh chose:
===Blonde Electra=== {{main|Blonde Electra}} '''Blonde Electra''' (formerly '''Blonde Electric''') are a duo consisting of half-English, half-German sisters Jazzy and Ruby King.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/s103/the-x-factor/news/a601335/x-factors-blonde-electric-we-want-to-give-simon-cowell-a-panic-attack.html|title=X Factor's Blonde Electric: 'We want to give Simon Cowell a panic attack'|last=Alexander|first=Susannah|date=5 October 2014|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> They have drawn comparisons to former ''X Factor'' contestants [[Jedward]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/tv/x-factor/402938/X-Factor-groups-top-three-Blonde-Electric-Only-The-Young-new-boyband|title=X Factor: Louis Walsh puts Blonde Electric, Only The Young, New Boyband in final 12|last=Percival|first=Ash|date=4 October 2014|work=[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]|publisher=[[Northern & Shell]]|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> Originally called Blonde Electric, they changed their name before the live shows. Explaining the reason for their name change, Jazzy said "Blonde Electric is a little too descriptive. We are going for an independent, strong woman that represents Blonde Electra. That is why, but I like it. I think it's got a good ring to it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/s103/the-x-factor/news/a602399/x-factors-blonde-electra-debut-wacky-hair-explain-recent-name-change.html|title=X Factor's Blonde Electra debut wacky hair, explain recent name change|last=Gordon|first=Naomi|date=9 October 2014|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref>
Blonde Electra were automatically eliminated in week 1 after receiving the fewest public votes, coming in 16th place.<ref name="Result 1"/>

===Only The Young=== {{main|Only The Young (band)}} '''Only The Young''' were a four-piece mixed group consisting of Mikey Bromley (20, [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]]), Parisa Tarjomani (21, [[Ramsgate]]), Betsy-Blue English (19, [[Brighton]]), and Charlie George (17, [[Chartham]]).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/tv/x-factor/397423/X-Factor-Only-The-Young-performed-at-Wembley-with-Cheryl|title=X Factor hopefuls Only The Young performed at Wembley gig with Cheryl|last=Kelly|first=Emma|date=1 September 2014|work=[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]|publisher=[[Northern & Shell]]|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> The group were created and are currently managed by Jo Perry.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bouwman|first1=Kimbel|url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/2013/May30_15_29_1.html|website=Hit Quarters|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> Only The Young previously featured [[George Shelley (singer)|George Shelley]], who auditioned for the show's [[The X Factor (UK series 9)|ninth series]] and was added to [[Union J]], who made the live shows, eventually finishing in fourth place in the semi-final. This was when Shelley was later replaced by Bromley.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/music/news/a1070905/its-only-the-youngs-2-year-anniversary-lets-celebrate-by-looking-back-at-their-journey-to-the-x-factor/|title=It's Only The Young's 2 year anniversary - Let's celebrate by looking back at their journey to The X Factor|work=Sugarscape}}</ref> While on the series, Only The Young released their version of [[Bobby "Boris" Pickett]]'s "[[Monster Mash]]" in aid of [[Teenage Cancer Trust]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.justgiving.com/OnlyTheYoung/|title=Only The Young is fundraising for Teenage Cancer Trust|publisher=[[Teenage Cancer Trust]]|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref> Before the show, they auditioned for [[Capital (radio network)|Capital's]] [[Summertime Ball]] on 21 June, and were chosen to perform at [[Wembley Stadium]] alongside [[Pharrell Williams]], [[Miley Cyrus]], [[David Guetta]], [[Enrique Iglesias]], [[Little Mix]] and many other artists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalfm.com/summertime-ball/news/only-the-young/|title=New Band Only The Young Win Chance To Perform At The Capital Summertime Ball|date=1 June 2014|publisher=[[Capital (radio network)|Capital]]}}</ref>
They were in the bottom two with Jake Quickenden in week three, but they were saved after receiving only Mel B's vote against them.<ref name="Result 3"/> They were automatically eliminated in week seven as the act with the fewest public votes on Saturday, coming in 7th place.
Two weeks after being voted off the show, the group announced their first headlining show which would be held in London's Under the Bridge on 28 December 2014, thus becoming the first act of the series to be successful after leaving the show. However, the group have since had to pull out of the event following the death of Tarjomani's mother on 21 December.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/x-factor-only-young-singer-4858151|title=X Factor: Only the Young singer Parisa Tarjomani's mum dies|first=Tufayel|last=Ahmed|date=22 December 2014|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
On 19 May 2015, the group announced that they had signed a record deal with [[Warner Music]]. The music video of their debut single "[[I Do (Only The Young song)|I Do]]" was released on 8 June 2015, but their [[YouTube]] account was hacked four days later, which led to its deletion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/music/news/a1078904/only-the-young-hacked/|title=Only The Young thank fans for their support following 'I Do' music video hacking drama|work=Sugarscape}}</ref> It was re-uploaded the next day (13 June), losing all its previous views. "I Do" was originally to be released on 31 July,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/i-do-single/id1014139057|title=iTunes - Music - I Do - Single by Only The Young|work=iTunes}}</ref> but to the migrant crisis in [[Calais]] preventing a lorry containing copies of their single coming into the UK, it had to be delayed by a week, instead being released on 7 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a661491/x-factors-only-the-young-forced-to-delay-single-release-due-to-calais-migrant-crisis.htmlD|title=X Factor's Only The Young forced to delay single release due to Calais migrant crisis|work=Digital Spy}}</ref> "I Do" debuted at number 53 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] on 14 August.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.musicweek.com/news/read/official-charts-analysis-dr-dre-tops-uk-albums-chart-with-non-physical-release/062601|title=Official Charts Analysis: Dr. Dre tops UK Albums Chart with non-physical release|last=Jones|first=Alan|date=14 August 2015|work=[[Music Week]]|publisher=Intent Media|accessdate=14 August 2015|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 6 November 2015, Tajormani announced her departure from the band via her blog.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alettertoparisa.com/2015/11/to-our-amazingfans-this-is-notsomething.html?m=1|title=A Letter to Parisa|last=Tarjomani|first=Parisa|date=10 November 2015|publisher=A Letter to Parisa|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> Only The Young then announced their split four days later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.j-14.com/posts/x-factor-band-only-the-young-breaks-up-parisa-tarjomani-leaves-group-76710|title="X Factor" Band Only The Young Breaks Up: Parisa Tarjomani Leaves Group - J-14|last=Hiramine|first=Brie|date=10 November 2015|publisher=J-14|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref>

===Overload Generation=== '''Overload Generation''' (formerly '''Overload''') were a five-piece boy band consisting of Ollie Garland (born 28 November 1994, 22, [[Bristol]]), Jordi Whitworth (born 27 March 1995, 22, [[Essex]]), Ryan Robertson (born 30 January 1996, 21 [[Essex]]), Joey Devries (born 10 August 1994, 22 [[Wales]]) and Andy Fowler (Previously in [[Only One Direction]]. news|url=http://www.exeterexpressandecho.co.uk/X-Factor-piece-boy-band-featuring-Crediton-man/story-23011957-detail/story.html|title=X Factor 2014 video: Eight piece boyband featuring Devon man Barclay Beales named as favourite to win|date=29 September 2014|work=[[Express & Echo]]|publisher=[[Local World]]|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> The members were all initially rejected at the bootcamp stage but were formed into a group by the judges because they felt they were too good to let them go.<ref name="unnamed boy band" /><ref name=":2">{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/who-made-through-x-factor-4384437|title=Who has made it through to the X Factor 2014 live finals? The 12 finalists profiled|last=O'Neill|first=Kara|date=5 October 2014|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref> Initially called the "New Boy Band", they later held a poll on the website to determine a new name and "Stereo Kicks" was chosen.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/x-factor-2014-stereo-kicks-4422140|title=X Factor 2014: Stereo Kicks is the new name for the New Boy Band and Twitter's not happy|last=O'Neill|first=Kara|date=11 October 2014|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=8 December 2014}}</ref>
Stereo Kicks landed in the sing-off during week two with Chloe Jasmine, but were saved when Walsh, Mel B and Cowell opted to send Jasmine home.<ref name="Result 2"/> They were in the sing-off again in week 4 against Lola Saunders. With Walsh and Mel B opting to save them, the result went to deadlock and Saunders was eliminated as the contestant with fewest public votes.<ref name="Result 4 part 2"/> With the eliminations of Blonde Electra and Overload Generation in week 1 and Only The Young in week 7, Stereo Kicks became Walsh's last remaining act in the competition. In week 8, they were eliminated against Lauren Platt after voting went to deadlock, becoming the last of Walsh's groups to leave the competition and finishing in fifth place.<ref name="Result 8"/> Their debut single "[[Love Me So]]" was released on 21 June 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/stereo-kicks-unveil-debut-single-love-me-so-listen__8993/|title=Listen to Stereo Kicks' debut single Love Me So|work=officialcharts.com}}</ref>
On 18 July, the group announced that they would be splitting up to pursue solo careers after their final performance together at Thorpe Park on 25 July, citing difficulties in getting a record deal as a factor in the split.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/StereoKicksOfficial/posts/776683005782203|title=A message to our fans…|date=18 July 2015|publisher=[[Facebook]]|accessdate=18 July 2015}}</ref>

page.title: Mechanics of Oscar Pistorius's running blades

revision.text:
{{Good article}} [[File:Oscar Pistorius 2 Daegu 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Oscar Pistorius]] running during the [[2011 World Championships in Athletics]] in [[Daegu]], South Korea]]
The '''mechanics of the running blades''' used by South African Paralympic runner [[Oscar Pistorius]] depend on [[Flex-Foot Cheetah|special]] [[carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer]] [[prosthesis|prosthetics]]. Pistorius has double below-the-knee [[amputations]] and competes in both non-disabled and [[T44 (classification)|T44]] amputee [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] events. Pistorius's eligibility to run in international non-disabled events is sanctioned by the International Association of Athletics Federations ([[IAAF]]).
Pistorius began running in 2004 after a rugby knee injury which led to rehabilitation at the [[University of Pretoria]]'s High Performance Centre<ref>{{citation|author=Mike Moon |title=Blade Runner: Oscar Pistorius is forcing the world to rethink what it means to be disabled |url=http://www.rdasia.com/article/2730/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AH3zjOKd?url=http://www.rdasia.com/article/2730/ |archivedate=29 August 2012 |magazine=[[Reader's Digest|Reader's Digest Asia]] |year=2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> with coach Ampie Louw.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/mysport/2312850/My-Sport-Oscar-Pistorius.html|author=Davies, Gareth A. (interviewer)|date=23 May 2007|title=My sport: Oscar Pistorius|publisher=The Daily Telegraph (London)|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> His first racing blades were fitted by South African [[prosthetist]] Francois Vanderwatt. Because he was unable to find suitable running blades in [[Pretoria]], Vanderwatt ordered some to be made by a local engineer at Hanger Orthopedic Group. These quickly broke, and Vanderwatt referred Pistorius to American prosthetist and Paralympic sprinter [[Brian Frasure]] to be fitted for carbon-fibre blades by [[Iceland]]ic company [[Össur]].<ref>{{citation|author=Felix Gillette |title=Racing tall: A Paralympian stands accused of getting an illegal leg up |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/left_field/2004/11/racing_tall.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AcuKt59K?url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/left_field/2004/11/racing_tall.html |archivedate=12 September 2012 |magazine=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=10 November 2004 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Pistorius's participation in non-disabled international sprinting competitions in 2007 raised questions about his use of running blades, and the IAAF amended their rules to ban the use of "any technical device that incorporates springs, wheels or any other element that provides a user with an advantage over another athlete not using such a device." After initial studies, Pistorius was ruled ineligible for competitions under these IAAF rules.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/athletics/2288489/IAAF-call-time-on-Oscar-Pistorius-dream.html|author=Knight, Tom|date=10 January 2008|title=IAAF call time on Oscar Pistorius' dream|publisher=The Daily Telegraph (London)|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> After further research was presented, the Court of Arbitration ([[Court of Arbitration for Sport|CAS]]) ruled that his running prostheses were not shown to provide a net competitive advantage over biological legs.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2008/may/18/olympicgames2008.athletics |author=Mackay, Duncan|date=18 May 2008|title=Diack relaxed over Pistorius's victory|publisher=The Observer|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> In 2012 Pistorius qualified for and competed in both the [[2012 Olympic Games]] and the [[2012 Paralympic Games]] using his running blades, becoming the first amputee sprinter to run in the Olympic Games.<ref>{{citation |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/oscar-pistorius-makes-history-double-amputee-sprinter-compete/story?id=16929845|title=Pistorius, 25, Is First Double-Amputee Sprinter to Compete in Olympic Games|author=Shaw, Alexis|publisher=ABC|date=4 August 2012|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref>
==Pistorius's athletics prostheses== The blades are [[transtibial prosthesis|transtibial prostheses]], meaning they replace legs and feet that are amputated below the knee (BK). They were developed by medical engineer [[Van Phillips (inventor)|Van Phillips]] who incorporated Flex-Foot, Inc., in 1984, and in 2000 sold the company to [[Össur]] which now (in 2012) manufactures the blades. They are designed to store kinetic energy like a spring, allowing the wearer to jump and run effectively.<ref>{{citation |title=A Personal Call to a Prosthetic Invention|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/02/sports/olympics/02cheetah.html?ref=sports|date=2008-07-02|accessdate=19 September 2012|publisher=New York Times|author=Pogash, Carol}}</ref>
[[File:Oscar Pistorius at International Paralympic Day, Trafalgar Square, London - 20110908.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Pistorius wearing [[Flex-Foot Cheetah]] blades]]
Carbon fibre is actually a [[carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer]], and is a strong, light-weight material used in a number of applications, including sporting goods like baseball bats, car parts, helmets, sailboats, bicycles and other equipment where rigidity and high [[strength-to-weight ratio]] is important. The polymer used for this equipment is normally [[epoxy]], but other polymers are also used, depending on the application, and other reinforcing fibres may also be included. In the blade manufacturing process, sheets of impregnated material are cut into square sheets and pressed onto a form to produce the final shape. From 30 to 90 sheets may be layered, depending on the expected weight of the athlete, and the mold is then autoclaved to fuse the sheets into a solid plate. This method reduces air bubbles that can cause breaks. Once the result is cooled, it is cut into the shape of the blades. The finished blade is bolted to a carbon fibre socket that is an intimate fit to each of Pistorius' legs. These are custom made and make up the bulk of the total cost, along with the assessment and setting up of the finished prostheses. Each limb costs between $15–18,000 USD.<ref name=blades />
Pistorius has been using the same Össur blades since 2004. He was born without [[fibula]]e and with malformed feet, and his legs were amputated about halfway between knee and ankle so he could wear prosthetic legs. He wears socks and pads which are visible above the sockets to reduce chafing and to prevent blisters, and the sockets have straps in the front that can be tightened to make the prosthesis fit more snugly.<ref>{{citation |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/column-pistorius-revolutionizes-olympic-notions|title=Column: Pistorius revolutionizes Olympic notions|author=Leicester, John|date=4 August 2012|accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref>
Pistorius uses custom-made spike pads on the blades. Before development of the pads, his spikes were changed by roughing up the surface and applying over-the-counter spikes by hand, but the results using this method were inconsistent. Research was conducted in Össur’s Iceland lab using a pressure-sensitive treadmill and film at 500 [[Frame rate|fps]] to measure the blade strike, and produced a spike pad which includes a midsole of two machine-molded pieces of foam of different densities to cushion impact, with a carbon fibre plate on the bottom. The developers attached the pad with contact cement, which can be quickly removed with the application of heat when the spike pad needs to be changed.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.fastcodesign.com/1670487/how-nike-made-track-spikes-for-oscar-pistorius-s-carbon-fiber-blades|title=How Nike Made Track Spikes For Oscar Pistorius’s Carbon Fiber Blades|author=Wilson, Mark|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
Because of the curved design, the blades have to be slightly longer than a runner's biological leg and foot would be. The blades replace the hinge of an ankle with elastic compression that bends and releases the blade with every stride, so the uncompressed blade leaves the user standing on tiptoe. They are designed to move forward, so have no heel support in the back. According to Josh McHugh of [[Wired Magazine]], "The Cheetahs seem to bounce of their own accord. It’s impossible to stand still on them, and difficult to move slowly. Once they get going, Cheetahs are extremely hard to control."<ref name=blades>{{citation |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/15.03/blade.html?pg=2&topic=blade&topic_set=|author=McHugh, Josh|date=March 2007|publisher=Wired Magazine|title=Blade Runner|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
==How the blades work== [[File:Oscar Pistorius-2.jpg|thumb|upright|Pistorius running in Iceland in 2007.]]
In 2007 Pistorius applied to run in non-disabled track meets. He was at first accepted, but questions quickly arose about whether the blades give him an unfair advantage. After initial research showed the blades did provide an advantage, the [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF) changed their rules to ban the use of technical devices that provide an advantage and ruled him ineligible to compete. Pistorius challenged the ruling with additional research and was reinstated by the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] (CAS) in 2008, meaning that he can continue to run in non-disabled meets as long as he uses the equipment that was studied in the research.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/aug/29/paralympics-2012-oscar-pistorius|title=Paralympics 2012: Oscar Pistorius shows what Paralympians can achieve|author=Bull, Andy|date=28 August 2012|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref>
Pistorius's performance in the early non-disabled races raised questions because of two major concerns: his pattern of running the races and his leg-swing times. Most sprinters spring out of the blocks with their fastest time and slow down as the race progresses, but Pistorius ran a "negative split," starting slowly and building up speed in the last half of the race (though he no longer uses this pattern). His average time was also less in the 400m race when compared to other runners than in the 200m.<ref>{{citation |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/olympics/2012/writers/david_epstein/08/03/oscar-pistorius-london-olympics/index.html|title=Fair or foul? Experts split over whether Pistorius has advantage|author=Epstein, David|date=4 August 2012|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> Controversy about the use of the blades persists, but the research provided considerable information on how they work in application, and other research is expected to follow.<ref>{{citation |url=http://theconversation.edu.au/pistorius-loss-to-oliveira-fuels-the-disruptive-technology-debate-9250|title=Pistorius' loss to Oliveira fuels the ‘disruptive technology’ debate|author=Lyons, Keith|date=3 September 2012|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref>
Non-disabled sprinters have calves and ankles that return and amplify the energy supplied by their hips and knees, while Pistorius compensates with additional work because he does not have calves and ankles with their associated tendons and muscles. An analysis published by ''[[Engineering & Technology]]'' magazine estimates that in using the blades, Pistorius must generate twice the power from his [[gluteal muscles|gluteal]] and [[quadriceps]] muscles that a normal sprinter would.<ref>{{citation |url=http://engtechmag.wordpress.com/2012/08/28/london-2012-paralympic-games-oscar-pistorius-blades-an-annotated-graphic|title=London 2012 Paralympic games, Oscar Pistorius’ blades – an annotated graphic|publisher=Engineering & Technology|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> Other sources also credit core abdominal muscles and a faster arm swing.<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.nbcolympics.com/video/track-and-field/science-of-olympics-how-oscar-pistorius-blades-work.html|title=Science of the Olympics: How Oscar Pistorius' blades work|publisher=NBC|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> His trainer estimates that about 85 percent of his power comes from his hips and the rest from his knees. This results in a gait that waddles slightly, as Pistorius swings his upper body to balance the springing action of the blades. The blades compress under his weight, then release as he moves forward, providing forward thrust from the tips as they return to their molded shape. As they spring off, he swings them slightly out to the side and throws them forward for the next stride.<ref name=blades />
Pistorius is always slow in starting a race because the flexible blades do not provide thrust out of the blocks. Pistorius must begin from an awkward position, swing his leg to the outside and pop straight up from the blocks to begin running, when the preferred method is to push off with horizontal force.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/06/sports/olympics/pistorius-eliminated-track-and-field-roundup.html?pagewanted=all|title=Pistorius Misses Chance at Final, but Remains Upbeat|publisher=The New York Times|author=Borden, Sam|date=5 August 2012|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2012/08/no-advantage-to-being-an-amputee-a-defense-of-oscar-pistoriuss-prostheses/260878|title='No Advantage to Being an Amputee': A Defense of Oscar Pistorius's Prostheses|author=Simpson, Jake|publisher=The Atlantic|date=8 August 2012|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> For the first 30 meters of a race, he keeps his head down and takes short, quick strides. As he establishes a rhythm, he can raise his head and increase his speed. While some runners jog up and down, losing energy, Pistorius directs energy forward, looking somewhat like he is rolling on wheels. He also compensates for the adjustments ankles make on the turns, breaking the curves into short, straight lines. According to his coach Ampie Louw, Pistorius may be able to use the inward lean to generate force and come out of a turn going faster.<ref name=blades />
==Research==
===Brüggemann study=== [[File:Oscar Pistorius, the first round of the 400m at the London 2012 Olympic Games.jpeg|thumb|left|Pistorius running in the first round of the 400m at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London]]
To resolve questions about the blades, Pistorius was asked to take part in a series of scientific tests in November 2007 at the [[German Sport University Cologne]] with Professor of [[Biomechanics]] Peter Brüggemann and IAAF technical expert Elio Locatelli. After two days of tests, Brüggemann reported that Pistorius used about 25 percent less energy expenditure than non-disabled athletes once he achieved a given speed. The study also found that he showed major differences in sprint mechanics, with significantly different maximum vertical ground return forces, and that the positive work or returned energy was close to three times higher than that of a human ankle. The energy loss in the blade during stance phase when the foot was on the ground was measured as 9.3 percent, while that of normal ankle joint was measured at 42.4 percent, showing a difference of more than 30 percent. Brüggemann's analysis stated that the blades allowed lower energy consumption at the same speed, and that the energy loss in the blade is significantly less than in a human ankle at maximum speed.<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.iaaf.org/news/printer,newsid=42896.htmx|title=Oscar Pistorius - Independent Scientific study concludes that cheetah prosthetics offer clear mechanical advantages|date=14 January 2008|publisher=IAAF|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> In December of that year, Brüggemann stated to ''[[Die Welt]]'' newspaper that Pistorius "has considerable advantages over athletes without prosthetic limbs who were tested by us. It was more than just a few percentage points. I did not expect it to be so clear."<ref>{{citation|title=Report: Artificial limbs give paralympic champion competitive edge|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/12/20/sports/athletics20.php|newspaper=[[International Herald Tribune]]|date=20 December 2007}}</ref> The study was published in 2008 in ''Sports Technology'',<ref>{{citation|url=http://users.auth.gr/~lmademli/Analysi_Vadisis/Pistorius_SportsTechnology2008.pdf |title=Biomechanics of double transtibial amputee sprinting using dedicated sprinting prostheses |first=Gert-Peter |last=Bruggemann |first2=Adamantios |last2=Arampatzis |first3=Frank |last3=Emrich |first4=Wolfgang |last4=Potthast |year=2008 |accessdate=3 October 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> but later researchers stated that the analysis "did not take enough variables into consideration". Commentators have also argued that the IAAF study did not accurately determine whether Cheetahs confer a net advantage because measuring the net advantage or disadvantage conferred on an athlete using Cheetahs is not possible given current scientific knowledge.<ref>{{citation|author=Jonathan Clayton|title=Oscar Pistorius vows to fight Olympics ban|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/athletics/article3186862.ece|newspaper=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=15 January 2008}}</ref> Second, the IAAF study may not have measured Pistorius’s performance against appropriate controls. IAAF used five non-disabled athletes, who run 400-meter races in similar times to Pistorius, as controls. However, because Pistorius was relatively new to the sport of running, he may not have trained enough to maximize his physical potential and reach his peak performance when the IAAF study was conducted. In March 2007, approximately 9 months before the IAAF study was conducted, Pistorius’s coach commented that Pistorius had not trained enough to achieve an upper body commensurate with the upper bodies of most elite sprinters. To obtain the most accurate understanding of how the prostheses affect Pistorius’s performance, he should be compared to athletes with similar physical potential. Consequently, the IAAF study may have been flawed because it compared Pistorius, who might have the physical potential to run faster than his current times, against athletes at their peak. <ref>Zettler, Patricia J. "Is It Cheating to Use the Cheetahs? The Implications of Technologically Innovative Prostheses for Sports Values and Rules." Boston University International Law Journal 27 (2009).</ref>
===Weyand, et al. study=== In 2008 a team of seven researchers conducted tests at [[Rice University]], including Peter Weyand, [[Hugh Herr]], Rodger Kram, Matthew Bundle and Alena Grabowski. The team collected [[metabolic]] and mechanical data by indirect [[calorimetry]] and ground reaction force measurements on Pistorius's performance during constant-speed, level treadmill running, and found that the energy usage was 3.8 percent lower than average values for elite non-disabled distance runners, 6.7 percent lower than for average distance runners and 17 percent lower than for non-disabled 400m sprint runners. At sprinting speeds of 8.0, 9.0 and 10.0 m/s, Pistorius produced longer foot to ground contact times, shorter leg swing times, and lower average vertical forces than able bodied sprinters. The team concluded that running on the blades appears to be physiologically similar but mechanically different from running with biological legs. The study was published several months later in the ''[[Journal of Applied Physiology]]''.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/specialsections/summerolympics/Does-Double-Amputee-Oscar-Pistorius-Have-an-Unfair-Advantage-at-the-2012-Olympic-Games-162598806.html#ixzz26wkjbD00|title=Does Double-Amputee Oscar Pistorius Have an Unfair Advantage at the 2012 Olympic Games?|author=Eveleth, Rose|date=23 July 2012|publisher=Smithsonian Magazine|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://jap.physiology.org/content/107/3/903.abstract|publisher=Journal of Applied Physiology|title=The fastest runner on artificial legs: different limbs, similar function?|first=Peter G.|last=Weyand|first2=Matthew W.|last2=Bundle|first3=Craig P.|last3=McGowan|first4=Alena|last4=Grabowski|first5=Mary Beth|last5=Brown|first6=Rodger|last6=Kram|first7=Hugh|last7=Herr|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref> Kram also stated that Pistorius's "rate of energy consumption was lower than an average person but comparable to other high-caliber athletes."<ref name=study>{{citation |url=http://www.denverpost.com/perspective/ci_21056327/cu-boulder-researchers-help-oscar-pistorius-become-first#ixzz26ya4Ropt|title= CU-Boulder researchers help Oscar Pistorius become first amputee to compete in Olympics: Research shows his prostheses are not an advantage|date=11 July 2012|author=Bryen, Whitney|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
The lightness and rigidity of the blade compared to muscle and bone may allow blade runners to swing their legs faster than non-disabled runners. In comments on the article, Peter Weyand and biomechanist Matthew Bundle noted that the study found that Pistorius re-positioned his legs 15.7 percent faster than most world record sprinters, allowing for a 15 to 30 percent increase in sprint speed.<ref name=study2>{{citation |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rami-hashish/oscar-pistorius-prosthetic-legs-advantage_b_1766417.html|title=Oscar Pistorius' Prosthetic Legs: Do They Give Him an Advantage Over Other Olympic Runners?|author=Hashish, Rami|publisher=Huffington Post|date=10 August 2012|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
===Grabowski, et al. study=== In 2008 a research team including Alena Grabowski, Rodger Kram and Hugh Herr conducted a follow-up study of single amputees with running blades which was published in ''[[Biology Letters]]''. Each of six amputees' affected leg performance was compared against that of their biological leg. The team measured leg swing times and force applied to the running surface on a high-speed treadmill at the Biomechanics Laboratory of [[the Orthopedic Specialty Hospital]], and also studied video of sprint runners from the Olympics and Paralympics. They found no difference in leg swing times at different speeds, and recorded leg swing times similar to that of non-disabled sprinters. They also found that single running blades reduced the foot to ground force production of the tested runners by an average of 9 percent. Because force production is generally considered the most significant factor in running speed, the researchers concluded that this reduction in force limited the sprinters' top speed. Grabowski also found that amputees typically increased their leg swing times to compensate for the lack of force.<ref>{{citation |url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2009/11/02/rsbl.2009.0729.abstract|title=Running-specific prostheses limit ground-force during sprinting|first=Alena M.|last=Grabowski1|first2=Craig P.|last2=McGowan|first3=William J.|last3=McDermott|first4=Matthew T.|last4=Beale|first5=Rodger|last5=Kram|first6=Hugh M.|last6=Herr|publisher=Biology Letters|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=19 September 2012}}</ref>
===Other discussion=== Discussion continues about the relative advantage or disadvantage of using the blades. Researchers and analysts also point out that the research studies are done on level, stationary treadmills, and do not measure performance from starting blocks or on actual curved tracks. They also do not take into account differences in physiology between amputees and non-amputees, who have such factors as musculature, blade height and weight and differences in blood circulation patterns due to the history of their limb loss.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www2.teamusa.org/US-Paralympics/Features/2012/August/04/American-blade-runner-Jarryd-Wallace.aspx?p=1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120806200822/http://www.teamusa.org/US-Paralympics/Features/2012/August/04/American-blade-runner-Jarryd-Wallace.aspx?p=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 August 2012 |title=American blade runner: Jarryd Wallace |author=Rosewater, Amy |date=4 August 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2012 }}</ref>
==2012 Paralympics== A controversy over the effects of running blade length arose at the [[2012 Paralympic Games]], as Brazilian runner [[Alan Oliveira]] and USA runner [[Blake Leeper]] changed to longer running blades within a few months before the 2012 Paralympic Games. This led to marked improvement in their running times. Pistorius complained after the 200m race that the blades provided artificially lengthened running strides, which would be an infringement of the [[International Paralympic Committee|IPC]] rules, regardless of that the blades were within the allowable height limits for the athletes concerned.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/paralympic-sport/9517308/Oscar-Pistorius-blade-controversy-sour-grapes-or-is-South-African-right-to-complain-about-Alan-Oliveiras-blades.html|title=Oscar Pistorius blade controversy: sour grapes or is South African right to complain about Alan Oliveira's blades?|author=Hart, Simon|date=3 September 2012|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> His complaint was supported by single-leg runners including [[Jerome Singleton]] and [[Jack Swift]], who called for the [[T43 (classification)|T43]] double blade and [[T44 (classification)|T44]] single blade classes to be separated in future events, as single blade runners were unable to adjust the height of the prostheses, and must always match the length of their biological leg with a running blade.<ref>{{citation|author=Sam Cunningham |title=Oscar 'right to fight' as Paralympics blades row speeds up |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-2198913/Oscar-Pistorius-right-fight-blades-row-speeds-up.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ATEzRGgf?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-2198913/Oscar-Pistorius-right-fight-blades-row-speeds-up.html |archivedate= 6 September 2012 |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=5 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The improvement in running time and the wide broadcast of the race results provided a public demonstration of how the blade length affects performance. Pistorius' stride length was actually 9 percent longer (2.2m vs 2.0m), but Oliveira took more strides (99 vs 92). The combination of stride length and stride rate led to a clearly unusual performance with the longer blades.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.sportsscientists.com/2012_09_01_archive.html |title=Pistorius vs Oliveira and Technology. Three quick thoughts on Round 4 |author=Tucker, Ross |date=September 2012 |accessdate=20 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920181750/http://www.sportsscientists.com/2012_09_01_archive.html |archivedate=20 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> Pistorius's management issued a statement saying that Pistorius is always 1.84 meters tall, regardless of what prostheses he wears, and that the decision to maintain this height for his running blades was an issue of fairness.<ref>{{citation|url=http://summergames.ap.org/article/column-history-maker-pistorius-hypocrite-too |title=Column: History-maker Pistorius a hypocrite, too? |author=Leicester, John |publisher=AP |date=5 September 2012 |accessdate=20 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112214542/http://summergames.ap.org/article/column-history-maker-pistorius-hypocrite-too |archivedate=12 January 2013 |df= }}</ref>

'''Nanda Prasad Adhikari''' (Nepali:नन्द प्रसाद अधिकारी) (1961 or 1962 - 22 September 2014) was a Nepali citizen who sought justice after his son was killed. Adhikari died, after an 11-month [[hunger strike]], demanding that the [[Nepal]]i government arrest the murderers of his son.<ref name=ekantipur>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekantipur.com/2014/09/22/headlines/Nanda-Prasad-Adhikari-passes-away/395462/|title=Nanda Prasad Adhikari passes away|publisher=Ekantipur|accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref>
Adhikari's son, Krishna Prasad Adhikari, was abducted from Chitwan during the [[Nepalese Civil War|Nepali Maoist Conflict]]. He was killed in Bakulahar Chowk in [[Chitwan District]] in June 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/portal/index.php?action=news_details&news_id=83666|title=Nanda Prasad's battle for justice comes to an end|publisher=My Republica|accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref> Nanda Prasad began a hunger strike protest along with his wife, Ganga Maya. The striking couple were admitted to [[Bir Hospital]] after their health conditions was deteriorated. Various human rights organizations stated their concern in connection with the Adhikari couple's demand and the strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inseconline.org/index.php?type=news&id=13370&lang=/proc/self/environ|title=HR Activists on Monitoring Mission For Adhikari Killing Investigation|publisher=INSEC|accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref> The [[Asian Human Rights Commission]] has requested the [[UNHRC|UN Human Right Council (UNHRC)]] to bring pressure upon the Nepali government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanrights.asia/campaigns/adhikari/|title=NEPAL:Justice for Adhikari Couple|publisher=Asian Human Right Commission|accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref>
Adhikari died at the age of 52 in Bir Hospital on 22 September 2014,<ref name=ekantipur /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nepalnews.com/index.php/news/39314-nanda-prasad-adhikari-passes-away|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140923073950/http://www.nepalnews.com/index.php/news/39314-nanda-prasad-adhikari-passes-away|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-09-23|title=Nanda Prasad Adhikari passes away|publisher=Nepal News|accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref> the 333rd day of his fast.
After the death of Nanda Prasad, the Government of Nepal was criticized by various human right organizations as well as the public. The [[National Human Rights Commission (Nepal)]] has expressed its serious concern regarding Nanda Prasad Adhikari´s death and Ganga Maya's continued strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://myrepublica.com/portal/index.php?action=news_details&news_id=83755|title=Adhikari died after refusing food, treatment: Govt|publisher=Nepal Republic Media|accessdate=2014-09-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924233059/http://myrepublica.com/portal/index.php?action=news_details&news_id=83755|archivedate=2014-09-24|df=}}</ref>

{{Infobox writer | name = Ned Vizzini | image = Ned Vizzini.jpg | imagesize = 200 px | caption = Ned Vizzini in 2011 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Edison Price Vizzini | birth_date = {{birth date|1981|4|4|mf=y}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[New York City]], United States}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|12|19|1981|4|4|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], US | occupation = Author | nationality = American | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = B.A., [[Computer Science]] | alma_mater = [[Hunter College]] | period = 1981–2013 | genre = [[Young adult fiction]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = {{plainlist| * ''[[Be More Chill]]'' * ''[[It's Kind of a Funny Story]]'' * ''[[House of Secrets (2013 novel)|House of Secrets]]}} |website = |spouse = Sabra Embury}}
'''Ned Vizzini''' (born '''Edison Price Vizzini''',<ref name="nyt">{{cite news |last=Yardley |first=William |date=December 20, 2013 |title=Ned Vizzini, 32, Dies; Wrote Teenage Novels |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/21/books/ned-vizzini-author-of-teenage-novels-dies-at-32.html |newspaper=New York Times |location= |publisher= |accessdate=December 21, 2013}}</ref> April 4, 1981 – December 19, 2013) was an American writer. He was the author of four [[young adult fiction|books for young adults]] including ''[[It's Kind of a Funny Story]]'', which [[NPR]] named #56 of the "100 Best-Ever Teen Novels" <ref>{{cite web|title=Best Young Adult Novels, Best Teen Fiction, Top 100 Teen Novels : NPR|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/08/07/157795366/your-favorites-100-best-ever-teen-novels|accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref> and which is the basis of the [[It's Kind of a Funny Story (film)|film of the same name]].
Vizzini suffered from [[Major depressive disorder|depression]],<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2527282/Ned-Vizzini-Young-adult-author-memoir-depression-film-Zach-Galifianakis-Emma-Roberts-commits-suicide-aged-32.html 'Young adult' author whose memoir about depression was made into Zach Galifianakis film commits suicide aged 32] ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 20 December 2013. Retrieved 21 December 2013.</ref> spending time in a [[psychiatric ward]] in his early 20s, and authoring several works about the illness. He was found dead in his native [[Brooklyn, New York]] after an apparent [[suicide]] from a fall, aged 32.<ref name="nyt"/>
==Early life== Ned Vizzini grew up primarily in the [[Park Slope, Brooklyn|Park Slope]] neighborhood of [[Brooklyn]] in [[New York City]]. He attended [[Stuyvesant High School]] in [[Manhattan]], graduating in 1999.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/news/newsreleases/2002/ned_vizzini.html |title=Teen Angst Author and Hunter College Student Ned Vizzini to Speak About Writing and Publishing At May 1 Book Signing |date=April 2002 |accessdate=November 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814080830/http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/news/newsreleases/2002/ned_vizzini.html |archivedate=August 14, 2007 }}</ref> Vizzini's characters and situations are said to be based upon his time spent at Stuyvesant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2006-11-07/art/too-hot-to-handle/|title=Too Hot to Handle|author=Catherine Wigginton|date=November 7, 2006|accessdate=April 28, 2008|publisher=Village Voice}}</ref>
==Career== Vizzini's first published work was an essay he submitted to the ''[[New York Press]]'', an [[alternative newspaper]], about winning honorable mention at the 1996 [[Scholastic Art & Writing Awards#The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards|Scholastic Art & Writing Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ned Vizzini {{!}} FAQ|url=http://nedvizzini.com/faq/#reader_75|work=What are ten important dates in your life and what happened on those dates?|accessdate=23 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524210631/http://www.nedvizzini.com/faq/#reader_75|archivedate=24 May 2013|df=}}</ref> As a freelance writer for the paper, he wrote about everything from family vacations to getting drunk in the street with other kids. The success of Vizzini's work earned him an invitation to contribute a teen-focused article to the ''[[New York Times Magazine]]''.<ref name="About">{{cite journal|title=Ned Vizzini (1981-)|journal=Something About the Author|year=2008|volume=179|pages=196–198}}</ref>
In May 1998, Vizzini's essay "Teen Angst? Nah!" appeared in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vizzini|first=Ned|title=Advice; Teen Angst? Nah! - New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/17/magazine/advice-teen-angst-nah.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=April 23, 2013}}</ref> Following this, several of his ''New York Press'' columns became the core of his first book, ''Teen Angst? Naaah....'' which is a [[memoir]] of his teenage years. It is a collection of short stories, most of which were originally published in ''The New York Press'' and ''The New York Times Magazine''. The book is broken down by years covering junior high through high school and beyond.<ref name="About" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Vizzini|first=Ned|title=Teen Angst? Naaah....|year=2002|publisher=Laurel Leaf|isbn=044023767X}}</ref>
Vizzini attended [[Hunter College]], located in Manhattan.
In 2004 his first novel ''[[Be More Chill]]'' was published. A review for the ''[[New York Times Book Review]]'' said that ''Be More Chill'', which is about a high school student named Jeremy Heere who gets a supercomputer pill in his brain that makes him cool, "is so accurate that it should come with a warning."<ref name="About" /> Others have criticized the book for its language and lack of a clear moral.<ref>{{cite web|title=Goodreads {{!}} Be More Chill by Ned Vizzini - Reviews, Discussion, Bookclubs, Lists|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/19476.Be_More_Chill#other_reviews|accessdate=April 23, 2013}}</ref> ''Be More Chill'' was later [[Be More Chill (musical)|adapted into a musical]] in summer 2015 with lyrics by [[Joe Iconis]] and premiered at New Jersey’s [[Two River Theatre]]. Three years later, an Off-Broadway production opened at the [[Signature Theater Company|Signature Theater]] in New York.
In 2006 Vizzini's second novel ''[[It's Kind of a Funny Story]]'' was published. It is based on his five-day stay in Brooklyn's [[New York Methodist Hospital|Methodist Hospital]] psychiatric ward. The book recounts fifteen-year-old Craig Gilner's battle with suicidal depression as a result of a taxing school year at Manhattan's Executive Pre-Professional High School that exacerbates his feeling of social inadequacy.<ref name="About" />
In 2012 Vizzini's third novel ''The Other Normals'' was published. It is an "alternative fantasy"<ref>{{cite web|last=Healy|first=Cat|title=The Other Normals « Beyond Books|url=http://beyondbooks.ca/?p=5494|accessdate=23 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120035530/http://beyondbooks.ca/?p=5494|archivedate=20 January 2013|df=}}</ref> about a teenager who falls into a fantasy world that is the basis of his favorite [[role-playing game]].
With [[Nick Antosca]], Vizzini wrote two episodes of the 2012 season of MTV's supernatural drama ''[[Teen Wolf (2011 TV series)|Teen Wolf]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title="Teen Wolf" Restraint (TV episode 2012) - IMDb|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2337419/|accessdate=April 23, 2013}}</ref>
In 2013, ''[[House of Secrets (2013 novel)|House of Secrets]]'', the first novel in a middle grade fantasy series by Vizzini and filmmaker [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]], was published. It debuted on the ''New York Times'' bestseller list, where it remained for four weeks. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the book an "A-" review.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fowler|first=Tara|title=House of Secrets Review {{!}} Book Reviews and News|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20690038,00.html|accessdate=April 23, 2013}}</ref>
His essays and criticism appeared in ''The New York Times'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Vizzini|first=Ned|title=Children’s Books - The Cardturner - By Louis Sachar - NYTimes.com|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/16/books/review/Vizzini-t.html?_r=0|accessdate=April 23, 2013}}</ref> ''[[Los Angeles Review of Books|The Los Angeles Review of Books]]'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Vizzini|first=Ned|title=Los Angeles Review of Books - A Grosser Power: A Contrarian Look At The Hunger Games|url=http://lareviewofbooks.org/article.php?type=&id=626&fulltext=1&media=|accessdate=April 23, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419032616/http://lareviewofbooks.org/article.php?type=&id=626&fulltext=1&media=|archivedate=April 19, 2013|df=}}</ref> and ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vizzini|first=Ned|title="Game of Thrones" parenting lessons - Salon.com|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/03/30/game_of_thrones_parenting_lessons/singleton/|accessdate=April 23, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805053251/http://www.salon.com/2012/03/30/game_of_thrones_parenting_lessons/singleton/|archivedate=August 5, 2012|df=}}</ref>
Vizzini spoke at schools and libraries around the world about mental health, writing, and how students can use writing as a medicine for mental health. He spoke at [[UCLA]]; [[The Dalton School]]; the [[Brooklyn Public Library|Brooklyn]], [[New York Public Library|New York]], and [[Chicago Public Library|Chicago]] Public Libraries; [[Murray State University]]; [[NYU]]; [[The National Council of Teachers of English]]; and a Master's Tea at [[Yale]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gotham-artists.com/ned_vizzini.html|title=How Not to Go Crazy in College|work=Gotham Artists|accessdate=February 26, 2012}}</ref>
Vizzini and Antosca were story editors on ABC's 2013 drama series ''[[Last Resort (U.S. TV series)|Last Resort]]''. They are the credited writers of the episode "Nuke It Out."<ref>{{cite web|title="Last Resort" Nuke It Out (TV episode 2012)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2473720/|accessdate=April 23, 2013}}</ref>
From 2006 to 2012 Vizzini facilitated a [[writing workshop]] for local [[teenager]]s. The workshops were held monthly in a [[Park Slope]] [[Barnes & Noble]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Teen Writing Workshop with Author Ned Vizzini|url=http://parkslope.patch.com/groups/schools/p/ev--teen-writing-workshop-with-author-ned-vizzini|publisher=Park Slope Patch|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> The teens who attended had the chance to have their work published on the group's blog, "Give Us Money."<ref>{{cite web|title=Teen Writing Workshop with Author Ned Vizzini - Barnes & Noble Park Slope|url=http://www.nymetroparents.com/brooklyn/2013neweventinfo.cfm?id=53748|publisher=Brooklyn parent|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref>
==Death== Vizzini, who often spoke and wrote about his struggles with severe clinical depression, died by suicide on December 19, 2013 in Brooklyn, New York, at the age of 32.<ref name="lat">{{cite web|last=Kellogg|first=Carolyn|title=Writer Ned Vizzini has died at 32|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-writer-ned-vizzini-has-died-20131220,0,6354622.story#axzz2o2TauLCt|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=20 December 2013}}</ref> The New York City chief medical examiner's office said he suffered blunt impact injuries. The writer's brother, Daniel, told reporters that Vizzini had jumped off the roof of the building where their parents live.<ref>Yardley, William (December 20, 2013). [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/21/books/ned-vizzini-author-of-teenage-novels-dies-at-32.html?ref=obituaries "Ned Vizzini, 32, Dies; Wrote Teenage Novels"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dailyentertainmentnews.com/breaking-news/sabra-embury-book-author-ned-vizzinis-wife-photos/ |title=Ned Vizzini & wife Sabra|publisher=Daily E News |accessdate=2013-12-15 |date=December 2013}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person |name=Pitu Guli
Питу Гули |birth_date= 1865 |birth_place= [[Krusevo]], [[Ottoman Empire]] (now the [[Republic of Macedonia]]) |death_date= August 12th, 1903 |death_place= [[Krusevo]], [[Ottoman Empire]] |image= PitoGuli.jpg |caption= |other_names=Pitu the Vlach |movement= |organization= [[Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization]] (IMRO) |monuments= [[Mečkin Kamen]] |awards= |footnotes= }} '''Pitu Guli''' ({{Cyrl|Питу Гули}}; 1865–1903) was an [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] revolutionary in [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]], a local leader of what is commonly referred to as the [[Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization]] (IMRO).Brown, K. (2003) ''The Past in Question: Modern Macedonia and the Uncertainties of Nation'' (Princeton: Princeton University Press) {{ISBN|0-691-09995-2}} ==Life== Born to a poor family in [[Krusevo|Kruševo]], he demonstrated an independent and rebellious nature early in life. He left his home in [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]] at the age of 17 in search of wealth in the [[Bulgaria]]n capital, [[Sofia]]. In 1885, he returned to Macedonia, as part of a rebel squad of the revolutionary movement against the [[Ottoman Empire]], led by Adam Kalmikov. He was captured and exiled to eastern Anatolia for a period of eight years, seven years of which were spent in the prison in [[Trabzon]]. In 1895, he again returned to Kruševo and became a member of IMARO. From this time on, he was fully committed to the independence of Macedonia from Turkish rule. Between 1897 and 1902 he was again in Sofia, where he also held an eating house. [[File:BASA 114K-1-26 Pitu Guli,1903.jpg|left|thumb|Pitu Guli and his squad in 1903. Source: Bulgarian Archives State Agency]] In March 1903, he began commanding a revolutionary squad, crossing the Bulgarian-Ottoman border heading for [[Kruševo]]. From April to August 1903, he trained and prepared his irregulars for the upcoming [[Ilinden-Preobrazhenie Uprising|Ilinden Uprising]]. He died in Krusevo, defending the [[Krusevo Republic]]. ==Legacy== Following the revolt, Romania, with the support of Austro-Hungary, succeeded in the acceptance of Vlachs as a separate [[millet]] with the decree ([[Irade-i senniye|irade]]) of May 22, 1905 by Sultan Abdulhamid, so the "Ullah millet" ([[Vlach Millet|the millet of the Vlachs]]) could have their own churches and schoolsThede Kahl, Ethnologia Balkanica, Vol. 6 (2002), p. 148 Nevertheless, Pitu Guli and his family were [[Bulgarophiles]].Коста Църнушанов, Македонизмът и съпротивата на Македония срещу него, Университетско изд. "Св. Климент Охридски", София, 1992, стр. 132.Тодор Балкански, Даниела Андрей, Големите власи сред българите, Знак 94, {{ISBN|9548709082}}, 1996, стр. 60-70. Except for [[Bulgarian Exarchate|Exarchist]] Vlachs,''Aromanian consciousness was not developed until the late 19th century, and was influenced by the rise of Romanian national movement. As result, wealthy, urbanized Ottoman Vlachs were culturally hellenised during 17-19th century and some of them bulgarized during the late 19th and early 20th. century.'' Raymond Detrez, 2014, Historical Dictionary of Bulgaria, Rowman & Littlefield, {{ISBN|1442241802}}, p. 520. most members of other ethnicities dismissed the IMRO as pro-Bulgarian.Andrew Rossos, Macedonia and the Macedonians: A History, Hoover Press, 2013, {{ISBN|081794883X}},p. 105.Philip Jowett, Armies of the Balkan Wars 1912–13: The priming charge for the Great War, Bloomsbury Publishing, 2012, {{ISBN|184908419X}}, p. 21. He is father of Tashko Gulev (Shula Guli), who died in 1913 as soldier of the Bulgarian army in the [[battle of Bregalnica]] against the Serbs, during the [[Second Balkan War]].Македоно-одринското опълчение 1912-1913 г. Личен състав, Главно управление на архивите, 2006, стр. 190. He is also father of the revolutionary of the IMRO, Nikola Gulev (Lakia Guli), one of the people closest to [[Todor Alexandrov]]. He was captured and killed by the Serbian police in 1924.Македонска енциклопедија, МАНУ, Скопје, 2009, стр. 415-416. Pitu Guli is a father of Steryo Gulev (Sterya Guli), who took part in the military units formed by the Bulgarian authorities in Vardar Macedonia during World War II to fight the communist [[Yugoslav partisans]]. He reportedly shot himself after Bulgarian withdrawal from Macedonia in 1944, upon the arrival of [[Josip Broz Tito|Tito]]'s partisans in Kruševo, in despair over what he saw as a second period of Serbian dominance in Macedonia.Historical Dictionary of the Republic of Macedonia, Dimitar Bechev, Scarecrow Press, 2009, {{ISBN|0810862956}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ilGfCIF4Ao4C&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91&dq=guli+macedonia+bechev&source=bl&ots=VvLWIPeVlY&sig=bPj_zZijSTmHvg5R9ELQivaiFls&hl=bg&sa=X&ei=m10kU_q5E-T9ygP6lYLoAQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 91.] Pitu Guli is a national hero in the Republic of Macedonia and Bulgaria, and remembered as having fought heroically at [[Mečkin Kamen]] (''Bear's Rock'') near Kruševo, where he was killed during the Ilinden Uprising in defense of the Macedonian [[Kruševo Republic]]. A [[Macedonian Partisans|Macedonian Partisan]] Brigade was named after him. He is also celebrated in folk songs and poetry throughout the region of Macedonia, being mentioned in the [[national anthem]] of the [[Republic of Macedonia]] (''[[Today over Macedonia]]''). ==References== {{commons category|Pitu Guli}} {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Guli, Pitu}} [[Category:1865 births]] [[Category:1903 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kruševo]] [[Category:Aromanian people]] [[Category:Members of the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization]] [[Category:Bulgarian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Ottoman Kruševo]] [[Category:Bulgarian people of Aromanian descent]]
